content.text: I'll help you understand Region Flexibility from a strategic business perspective. Let me first gather some internal information about this capability.

Service owners can use this tool at any point of their infrastructure set up ( build, host ordering, scaling, descaling and clean-up) while also providing the ability to monitor progress through completion of the DARU initiative.","displayTitle":"ReFlex MaX","domain":"tool","resultType":"document","resultId":"46f414bd-afc9-4872-90e1-958d2a292778","modificationDate":1743435496905,"interestGroup":"https://email-list.corp.amazon.com/email-list/expand-list/deltatools-interest","resourceType":null,"status":"production","documentationUrl":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Last_Mile_And_Middle_Mile/REALM/Trans_DevOps/Tool_Development/ReFlex_MaX/","ownerList":["TEAM$Squid-Team"],"sageTagList":null,"score":51.6397,"ownedByAmazon":true,"sourceCodeUrl":"https://code.amazon.com/packages/SquidUIServiceWebsite","rank":1,"categoryList":[]},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/IN-Region-Flexibility/","displayTitle":"IN Region Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1740419757000,"score":0,"rank":1,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [IN Region Flexibility][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Owner **[ in-region-flexibility \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n \\n \\n Last modified 5 months ago by [paparaoc][3].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][4]\\n {{transclude name=\\"INRegionFlexibility\\"/}}\\r\\n\\r\\n{{comment}}\\r\\n The template for the IN Regional Flexibility wiki can be found at https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Templates/INRegionFlexibility/\\r\\n{{/comment}}\\r\\n\\r\\n{{container cssClass=\\"floatinginfobox\\"}}\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% border=\\"1\\" %\)\\r\\n|\(% style=\\"border-right:2.5px solid #00004d; border-left:2.5px solid #00004d; padding-right:25px; padding-left:25px; width:30%\\" %\)\(\(\(\\r\\n\\r\\n{{toc/}}\\r\\n\\r\\n== Problem Scope ==\\r\\nOver the next 18-24 months the Stores, Devices, and Other \(SDO\) organization will move 25%+ of our OLTP data across AWS regions to provide operational flexibility and overcome scaling constraints for our existing and new marketplace expansion. Region flexibility is an SDO led initiative aimed at simplifying the efforts to get SDO services rapidly into new or existing AWS regions to address operational and regulatory challenges. Since 2020, SDO has been investing in components of regional flexibility by enabling technologies: Service Configuration Discovery and Routing \(Axon, Almanac, Veritas, Planisphere, others\), Data analysis \(Metador, Andes, others\) and movement \(Hotwire/LMT, GlobeMaster, CDMS\). While these investments allowed us to address specific pain points, Service/Application owners \(Builders\) are required to assemble these services to build out and execute a migration recipe that meets their need and addresses constraints. What is missing is a guided, friction-less customer experience or unified solution for Builders to orchestrate \(fully/semi-automated or manual\) migrations that addresses dependencies, run time latency needs, and shared data access constraints, while still keeping their business running.\\r\\n\\r\\nAs an example, the Region Flexibility team may want to stand up \(all\) the necessary services for an experience in a new region, then migrate the data necessary for the experience incrementally and atomically \(e.g. such that all the data for a specific customer appears in the new region together\). This requires understanding the services' upstream and downstream dependencies, along with the computational views that the services consume. It also requires orchestrating data movement to aid functional debugging, validation, and auditing. Doing these migrations without coordination will be resource intensive for application owners and builders.\\r\\n\\r\\n== Our Vision ==\\r\\nEnable SDO's businesses to operate outside of our existing \\"mega-regions\\" of IAD, DUB, and PDX; and enable the movement of traffic across AWS regions for the purposes of cost-efficiency, availability, change in legal compliance requirements etc. without effort from the service owner. The North Star for region flexibility is to centrally deploy services to new or expanding regions and move data and customer traffic between regions in a matter of months without negatively impacting service owners or customers. In short, most service owners should not need to know where their systems and data reside.\\r\\n\\r\\nThe IN Region Flexibility team's charter focuses on three core objectives: 1\) Execute DARU S-Team Goal compliance and facilitate DUB exit for IES by EOY 2026; 2\) Drive IES services to be 100% region flexible with optimal investments and overall org productivity enhancements; and 3\) Develop robust region and data migration tooling via strategic collaboration with WW Region Flex Engineering \(RFE\) and Managed Migration Experience \(M2X\) organizations. \\r\\n\\r\\nThe IN Region Flexibility team owns UI console and Testing Framework in this initiative and is responsible for establishing new solutions and architectural patterns in these fields to help services owners get into regions more quickly, in partnership with different teams at Amazon.\\r\\n\\r\\n== Program Overview ==\\r\\nhttps://w.amazon.com/bin/view/IN-Region-Flexibility/Overview/\\r\\n\\r\\n== Tenets ==\\r\\n\\r\\n\[TBD\]\\r\\n\\r\\n== Architecture ==\\r\\n\\r\\n\[\[image:https://maxis-file-service-prod-dub.dub.proxy.amazon.com/issues/cabe9f31-df17-4958-8ff5-d2aaa7c6e548/attachments/e693b07c32ba24ff14c5674857d1681c8cf20e973beca1924f7bc6db881c4c26\_1b2ac41c-af1a-46f2-9b72-1b0990552717||width=\\"50%\\"\]\]\\r\\n\\r\\n\*\*Coordinator\*\* is an umbrella service which contains various different services/component. It is an orchestration service that delegates the entire migration process to various tools and components. These various tools and components will also depend on what type of migration a customer wants to perform.\\r\\n\\r\\n\*\*MetaDor\*\* is the the component that will power the discovery experience over the MetaData UI console. MetaDor will be the source of information for getting information required to enable migrations on service/dataset level. These informations will be used to prepare migration entity, MODs and MEDs.\\r\\n\\r\\n\*\*DRA\*\* is the component which will keep track of status of entities under migration and enable in routing traffic to proper region.\\r\\n\\r\\n\*\*Data Movement Services\*\* is the component which will actually move the data, i.e, perform migration. It will also provide capabilities to Coordinator to start/stop/terminate migration at Dataset/service level. One of the example if this service is CDMS which is is a suite of data movement solutions for SDO data owners who need to move their data across AWS regions, partitions, accounts and storage technologies.\\r\\n\\r\\nThe detailed architecture for the entire Region Flexibility program can be found here https://broadcast.amazon.com/channels/64990/videos.\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n== Related Terminologies ==\\r\\nhttps://quip-amazon.com/G2aSAoR1EpHr/M2X-Domain-Terminology\\r\\n\\r\\n== LEADERSHIP ==\\r\\n\\r\\n{{transclude name=\\"HyperBadge\\" args=\\"\\r\\n |username=anupkr\\r\\n Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1684112380000,"score":0,"rank":2,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [Region Flexibility][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Owner **[ sps-tech-pmo \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n \\n \\n Last modified 2 years ago by [sssrid][3].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][4]\\n {{transclude name=\\"CARML.TechPMO\\"/}}\\n\\n{{toc numbered=\\"true\\"/}}\\n\\n= Region Flexibility Program Overview =\\n\\nRegion Flexibility refers to Amazon’s ability to run its businesses by utilizing compute capacity from a growing set of AWS regions. This gives Amazon more options to bring functionality closer to customers, leverage compute supply across wider geographies, and in certain cases like Enfield, comply with data privacy legislation. There are a growing set of important and timely reasons for SDO to be able to operate across a wider set of AWS regions than we do today. To accomplish this, SDO must be able to move data and software with much more agility across AWS regions.\\n\\nIn 2022, Region Flexibility Program\(% style=\\"--original-color:#16191f; color:#16191f\\" textcolor=\\"#16191f\\" %\) team partnered with SDO teams for a series of \(%%\)\*\*Investigations \*\*\(% style=\\"--original-color:#16191f; color:#16191f\\" textcolor=\\"#16191f\\" %\)into areas that will be important or problematic for region flexibility, but where there is no good idea of a path forward. These investigations resulted in new ideas for \(%%\)\*\*Accelerators\*\*\(% style=\\"--original-color:#16191f; color:#16191f\\" textcolor=\\"#16191f\\" %\) \(projects that will speed up the work teams have to do, or reduce the likelihood of manual error\) and \(%%\)\*\*Enablers\*\*\(% style=\\"--original-color:#16191f; color:#16191f\\" textcolor=\\"#16191f\\" %\) \(projects required to make migration feasible, often by reducing cross-team coordination\).\(%%\) Region Flexibility teams asked SDO teams to contribute in building the Enablers and Accelerators \(EAs\) in 2023.\\n\\n== What's New for 2023? ==\\n\\nIn 2023, WW SPS teams planned to allocate 8 HC to work in resource loaner model on Regional Flexibility Enablers and Accelerators Projects. These 8 HC will be working on these 3 EAs \(1\) Safe Rules Rollout, \(2\) Run Test Migrations, and \(3\) Eliminate need for ClientConfig to support a realm before calls can be started. \\n\\n= 2023 Goals & Mechanisms =\\n\\n== 2023 Goals ==\\n\\n{{html}}\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n\\r\\n

2eLTShift test data and traffic for three SDO domain entities residing in Sable between two regions by using a prototype of the Managed Migration eXperience \(M2X\)jhorak@565187

SPS - Dharmesh Mehta, Sriram Krishnan, Mary Beth Westmoreland, Priya Padmanabhan, Benjamin Hartman, Dave Montague, Rohan Oommen, Garret Gaw\\n\\n= Questions or Feedback? =\\n\\nPlease contact {{transclude name=\\"InlinePhoneTool\\" args=\\"vkarum|Vamsee Karumudi - Senior Technical Program Manager|1.5\\"/}}\\n"} [1]: \"/bin/view/SPSCoreServices/TechPMO/RegionFlexibility/\" [2]: \"https://permissions.amazon.com/group.mhtml?group=sps-tech-pmo&group_type=ldap\" [3]: \"/bin/view/XWiki/sssrid\" [4]: \"/bin/view/SPSCoreServices/TechPMO/RegionFlexibility/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\""},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region_Flexibility/","displayTitle":"Region Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1755187652000,"score":0,"rank":3,"categoryList":["Region Flex"],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [Region Flexibility][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Owner **[ region-flexibility-engineering-all \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n \\n \\n Last modified 1 day ago by [rohanso][3].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][4]\\n {{transclude name=\\"Buckeye\\"/}}\\n\\n{{toc depth=\\"2\\"/}}\\n\\n\\n\(% class=\\"box infomessage\\" %\)\\n\(\(\(\\nIf you are here because you received a Policy Engine violation or an email about submitting your services migration plans in \[\[Region Flexibility Portal>>https://ui.rfe.amazon.dev/\]\], please follow the \[\[instructions >>https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Migration\_Plans/\]\]as specified in the Policy Engine or contact rfe-tpm@ for further clarification.\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\If you think you are \_\_\*\*wrongly flagged as in scope\*\*\_\_ for a sub-experience migration, you should contact sub-experience Migration Coordinator responsible for managing the scope to resolve the issue. You can determine sub-experience Migration Coordinator by inspecting flagged sub-experiences in the Region Flexibility Portal. If you still can't find the right owner you can submit a SIM to RFE to \[\[here>>https://sim.amazon.com/issues/create?template=1c116a08-1719-46d7-8983-92d3604ce790\]\]. Please note, RFE provides the guidance to sub-experience owners based on Axon, AAA, other data sources, to try and help them determine the transitive closure of dependencies that will cause a latency regression if broken up, but we don't \(% data-stringify-type=\\"italic\\" %\)//know//\(%%\) these things perfectly. So, please follow instructions as outlined above.\\n\)\)\)\\n\\n== This Week In Region Flex ==\\n\\nAre you interested in seeing the new Sharepoint? \[\[image:https://emoji.slack-edge.com/T015GUGD2V6/office\_cat/0a4ca810143e4655.png||alt=\\":office\_cat:\\" aria-label=\\"office cat emoji\\" data-stringify-emoji=\\":office\_cat:\\" data-stringify-type=\\"emoji\\" height=\\"25\\" width=\\"25\\"\]\]\\nCurious about the opinions and learnings going on across region-flex? \[\[image:https://emoji.slack-edge.com/T015GUGD2V6/cathuh/3482520a5142ad79.gif||alt=\\":cathuh:\\" aria-label=\\"cathuh emoji\\" data-stringify-emoji=\\":cathuh:\\" data-stringify-type=\\"emoji\\" height=\\"25\\" width=\\"25\\"\]\]\\nLooking for insights about what the leaders in AWS and SDO think about the program? \[\[image:https://emoji.slack-edge.com/T015GUGD2V6/meow\_nod/9532e8a73b2dc42c.gif||alt=\\":meow\_nod:\\" aria-label=\\"meow nod emoji\\" data-stringify-emoji=\\":meow\_nod:\\" data-stringify-type=\\"emoji\\" height=\\"25\\" width=\\"25\\"\]\]\\nHoping to see your team's work in a blog article? \[\[image:https://emoji.slack-edge.com/T015GUGD2V6/gr-coding/1c0002f0514f7a3e.gif||alt=\\":gr-coding:\\" aria-label=\\"gr coding emoji\\" data-stringify-emoji=\\":gr-coding:\\" data-stringify-type=\\"emoji\\" height=\\"25\\" width=\\"25\\"\]\]\\nThen check out a new article series authored by RFE, \\"\[\[This Week in Region Flex>>https://amazon.sharepoint.com/sites/RegionFlexibility/\_layouts/15/News.aspx\]\]\\"!\\n\\n//Don't have the new Sharepoint yet? \[\[image:https://emoji.slack-edge.com/T015GUGD2V6/gr-sadcat/d4e64513bd2ca419.png||alt=\\":gr-sadcat:\\" aria-label=\\"gr sadcat emoji\\" data-stringify-emoji=\\":gr-sadcat:\\" data-stringify-type=\\"emoji\\" height=\\"26\\" width=\\"26\\"\]\] or just want to get an email version in your inbox? join: \[\[this-week-in-region-flex@amazon.com>>path:mailto:this-week-in-region-flex@amazon.com||aria-haspopup=\\"menu\\" data-sk=\\"tooltip\_parent\\" data-stringify-link=\\"mailto:this-week-in-region-flex@amazon.com\\" delay=\\"150\\" rel=\\"noopener noreferrer\\" target=\\"\_blank\\"\]\] to get more emails. //\[\[image:https://a.slack-edge.com/production-standard-emoji-assets/14.0/google-medium/1f4eb@2x.png||alt=\\":mailbox:\\" aria-label=\\"mailbox emoji\\" data-stringify-emoji=\\":mailbox:\\" data-stringify-type=\\"emoji\\"\]\]\\n\\n== Exit DUB 2026 Planning Timeline ==\\n\\n\* --5/15/2025-- 5/30/2025 - Release 2026 OP1 planning document for all L8 organizations in scope of Exit DUB migrations. The document will be distributed to organizational leaders and \[\[published here>>https://amazon.awsapps.com/workdocs-amazon/index.html#/document/17c8eb0907c8ca3d845d4beab9dad188dcea2ecd05ef450842c1f4cd49fbada2\]\].\\n\* 9/30/2025 - Start 2026 organizational and sub-experience planning with Migration Coordinators and SPOCs.\\n\* 11/30/2025 - Complete Sub-experience planning, create identified sub-experiences in the Region Flexibility Portal, and launch planning Policy Engine campaigns to individual service owners.\\n\* 11/30/2025 - Define 2026 CCI and S-team Goals.\\n\* 12/30/2025 - Complete 2026 Cross-SDO Organizational Plans.\\n\\n== Overview ==\\n\\nRegion Flexibility aims to make it easy to serve existing SDO \(Stores, Devices, and Other\) customer traffic from new AWS regions. This will require a few key changes:\\n\\n1. \*\*Expand to additional regions. \*\*Get into more regions! De-concentrate out of our primary AWS regions today - DUB, IAD, and PDX - in order to grow and scale despite challenges such as physical limitations, changes in compliance legislation, and to reduce the blast radius of outages. It's been over a decade since SDO as a whole has gotten into new regions, and we'll need to re-learn what it takes.\\n1. \*\*Support additional latency where it's appropriate and frugal. \*\*Enable SDO to leverage additional availability zones \(AZs\) and regions that are more distant than our services expect today. We'll drive experiments to assess and moderate the impact of both intra-service and inter-service latency, and leverage in-development service and data graphs to identify where minimal latency can be introduced into the service graph.\\n1. \*\*Make multi-region marketplaces possible \(splitting .com\). \*\*Enable a single marketplace to be served across multiple regions in the steady state. We'll need this approach for our largest marketplaces, such as the US, where one region can't sustain us forever, and when smaller marketplaces pass localization legislation. By splitting use cases or customers across AWS regions, we can improve our ability to mitigate region-specific capacity constraints.\\n\\n== Grand Vision ==\\n\\nServices and data are automatically placed in the region\(s\) and AZ\(s\) they’re needed without builder effort or awareness, and guardrails ensure all new services stay region flexible from creation.\\n\\n== What can I move now? ==\\n\\nAWS region in ZAZ is open for use in SDO.\\n\\nAWS region in FRA reached the \*\*General Availability\*\* milestone as of December 30 2024. It is now open to all SDO teams to build services. \_\_Please note the \(% class=\\"wikiinternallink\\" %\)\[\[\(% class=\\"wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink\\" %\)\*\*Known Open Issues for MAWS FRA customers\*\*>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Tech\_Guidance/Deep\_Dives\_and\_Announcements/MAWS\_FRA/#HKnownOpenIssuesforMAWSFRAcustomers\]\]\(%%\) section below that describes any SDO features not yet available in FRA.\_\_ \\n\\nIn 2024, all services that are async, latency tolerant, or don't have a direct impact on customer facing experiences should migrate from DUB to ZAZ. To get started, check out \[\[Per-Service Migration Guide>>https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Tech\_Guidance/Per-Service\_Region\_Migration\_Guide/\]\].\\n\\nIn 2025, we will begin moving customer facing experiences and expect ES, UK, and parts of IT, FR, and IN marketplaces to be served out of ZAZ and a portion of DE marketplace out of FRA by 12/30/25. To get started please review SDO's \[\[Exit DUB Strategy>>https://wiki.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Tech\_Guidance/Deep\_Dives\_and\_Announcements/Announcements/Exit\_DUB\_Strategy/\]\] and \[\[Sub-experience Migration Coordination>>https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Coordinating\_Migrations/\]\] wikis. \\n\\n== Vision ==\\n\\nWe envision a future where latency-sensitive workloads operate in the region closest to our customers, and latency-insensitive workloads operate in the least expensive region that meets regulatory requirements. In this future, most services are agnostic of where their business logic and data reside, and only provide constraints and scaling signals to a central placement system solving for the Amazon-wide optimal solution balancing capacity availability signals from AWS, the optimal customer experience, regulatory compliance, and cost efficiency. With greater flexibility, peak events that require scaling beyond the available capacity of a single region can be served simultaneously from multiple regions, reducing our peak-to-mean spread and reducing CAPEX. \\n\\nTo accomplish this, we need to intentionally iterate on architectures that abstract networking and infrastructure management \(e.g., moving to higher-level abstractions\), reduce the number of architectural patterns SDO teams employ to build their services, improve the abstraction of telemetry and observability capabilities, and centralize the optimization of undifferentiated decisions currently made imperfectly due to distributed ownership \(e.g., placement of capacity, timeout management, data migrations\). \\n\\nWe begin by building core components that enable and reduce the effort of our most urgent cross-region moves, while guiding individual teams to adopt solutions and foundational systems that meet them at their current architectural abstraction and maturity \(e.g., provide solutions for each of Lambda, managed runtimes, and JVM-on-EC2/ECS\). We then intentionally build on the learnings from cross-region migrations into these central solutions and patterns, evolving SDO services with minimum builder toil \(e.g., ship features via merge-from-live\). \\n\\n\\nLearn more at our \[\[definition of a region flexible service>>https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Tech\_Guidance/Deep\_Dives\_and\_Announcements/Definition\_of\_a\_Region\_Flexible\_Service/\]\].\\n\\n== Tenets \(% style=\\"font-size:22px\\" %\)\(//Unless you know better...\)//\(%%\) ==\\n\\n//\*\*Region Flexibility \(Updated August, 2023\)\*\*//\\n\\n1. We will use this moment to make multi-year decisions, region flex means multiple regions //and// multiple moves over a long time horizon.\\n1. Region flexibility is a requirement for business continuity. We create visibility into the risks from choices, and ramifications of non-compliance using our best practices, guidance, and compulsory directives.\\n1. Region flexibility is not a lever for all deprecations, migrations, or tech-debt reductions; we prefer fewer coordinated parts to achieve our vision vs more.\\n1. Solution uniformity is a strategy, not a goal, no one solution will fit all; however customizations and bespoke solutions are expensive in the long term.\\n1. We prefer to provide precision in our shepherding of teams and migrations, employing central visibility, data, and tooling; but accept that our guidance must be sufficient where ambiguity exists.\\n1. Our data is precious and democratized; we are accountable and transparent in all we do and prioritize data accuracy ahead of recency to ensure we maintain trust with our partners.\\n\\n//\*\*Exit DUB \(Updated June, 2024\)\*\*//\\n\\n1. \(% style=\\"tab-stops:list .25in\\" %\)Supporting capacity assurance for Amazon and AWS customers is higher priority than architectural improvements or making services region flexible. Where these enhancements do not add risk, Amazon intentionally invests in them.\\n1. \(% style=\\"tab-stops:list .25in\\" %\)Experience owners, in partnership with RFE, own the responsibility of business continuity and impact in both duration and magnitude to the customer experiences \(e.g., latency, availability\); RFE will help resolve these decisions and provide visibility at appropriate business levels.\\n1. \(% style=\\"tab-stops:list .25in\\" %\)RFE owns enabling and guiding SDO teams, identifying broadly impacting bottlenecks, regulating the federated impact of owners’ actions, and auditing progress on migrations and region flexibility. SDO teams own migrating their services & data and making those systems region flexible.\\n1. \(% style=\\"tab-stops:list .25in\\" %\)Decoupling the work of individual teams as they set up their services, experiment, and make their data accessible cross-region is a priority for meeting exit DUB timelines.\\n1. \(% style=\\"tab-stops:list .25in\\" %\)RFE prefers to move data and workloads fewer times but recognizes this will not always be feasible \(e.g., first move IN Shopping experiences to ZAZ, then HYD\).\\n\\n== What does the Region Flexibility team do? ==\\n\\nThe Region Flexibility team is responsible for establishing new solutions and architectural patterns to help services owners get into regions more quickly, in partnership with experts at Amazon working in domains like data and configuration. We own the vision for how SDO gets into new regions, and influence which regions we move into considering regulatory requirements, latency, cost efficiency, and developer experience. You can review solutions that we are developing under \\"Accelerators\\" section.\\n\\n== How does Region Flexibility impact me as a service owner? ==\\n\\nToday, most of the work to get into new regions is on service owners. While the Region Flexibility team's goal is to eventually automate this work, we have a long way to go, and we expect our first region expansion/migration programs will be the most manual. Service owners are expected to set up their services in new region and then migrate their data and traffic, potentially in coordination with other teams. Our best knowledge on what it takes to get into a new region is captured in our \[\[Per-Service Region Migration Guide>>https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Tech\_Guidance/Per-Service\_Region\_Migration\_Guide/\]\] and in our \[\[Region Flex Portal>>https://ui.rfe.amazon.dev/\]\].\\n\\nAs you work through your first region expansion efforts, look for where automation could help you in the future, and either do that work now, capture it for the future, or where a solution could be widely reusable, share with the Region Flexibility team!\\n"} [1]: \"/bin/view/Region_Flexibility/\" [2]: \"https://permissions.amazon.com/group.mhtml?group=region-flexibility-engineering-all&group_type=ldap\" [3]: \"/bin/view/XWiki/rohanso\" [4]: \"/bin/view/Region_Flexibility/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\""},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Last_Mile_And_Middle_Mile/REALM/EPIC/RegionFlexibility/","displayTitle":"Region Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1709232107000,"score":0,"rank":4,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [Region Flexibility][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Contact **[hkhinda \(user\)][2]_[ How do I change this value?][3]_\\n \\n \\n Last modified 1 year ago by [hkhinda][4].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][5]\\n {{transclude name=\\"space:TransportationFrontline.REALM-EPIC.HeaderTemplate\\"/}}\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\nRegion Flexibility aims to make it easy to serve existing SDO \(Stores, Devices, and Other\) customer traffic from new AWS regions. This will require a few key changes:\\r\\n\\r\\n1. \*\*Expand to additional regions. \*\*Get into more regions! De-concentrate out of our primary AWS regions today - DUB, IAD, and PDX - in order to grow and scale despite challenges such as physical limitations, changes in compliance legislation, and to reduce the blast radius of outages. \\r\\n1. \*\*Support additional latency where it's appropriate and frugal. \*\*Enable SDO to leverage additional availability zones \(AZs\) and regions that are more distant than our services expect today. \\r\\n1. \*\*Make multi-region marketplaces possible \(splitting .com\). \*\*Enable a single marketplace to be served across multiple regions in the steady state. We'll need this approach for our largest marketplaces, such as the US, where one region can't sustain us forever, and when smaller marketplaces pass localization legislation. By splitting use cases or customers across AWS regions, we can improve our ability to mitigate region-specific capacity constraints.\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\n\(% lang=\\"EN-CA\\" style=\\"font-size:10.0pt\\" %\)\*\*Regional Flexibility \(RF\)\*\* is an initiative that compliments DARU. RF will enable and accelerate migrations to newer regions to address significant technology challenges and enable SDO’s services to become region-flexible. RF helps to migrate off of incompatible and unavailable infrastructure, like NetScaler load balancer, Sentry, Simple DB, etc. There is a multi-resiliency effort driven and hotly debated by ATS PEs, and the availability of the ZAZ region will drive those discussions. However, here we focus on the DARU and RF goals and the scope for ATS, Last Mile, and DEX. The below goals were committed by Udit in one of the S-Team meetings. To ensure we deliver on these committed goals, we evaluated how the REALM team can help the ATS organization deliver on the goals.\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\n\(% style=\\"font-size: 14px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif\\" %\)Refer to the Region Flexibility \[\[wiki>>https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/\]\] for more details.\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n= S-Team Goals for 2024 =\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\n\(% lang=\\"EN-CA\\" style=\\"font-size:10.0pt\\" %\)SDO RF goal is to prepare for operating in new regions. \(%%\)To prepare for operating in new regions, and specifically ZAZ in 2024 teams MUST:\\r\\n ~1. Confirm their workloads are not using Sentry ~/~/or~/~/ Move off of Sentry. Websites cannot use Sentry in snowforted regions \(including ZAZ\).\\r\\n 2. Migrate off of Public and Internal AWS services that will not be available in new regions by default as part of global expansion. This list to be provided via policy engine campaign to all SDO services hosted in DUB.\\r\\n 3. Move off of NetScaler load balancers leveraging guidance provided by the ReBalance program. NetScalers will not be available in ANY new regions.\(% lang=\\"EN-CA\\" style=\\"font-size:10.0pt\\" %\)\(\[\[\(% class=\\"wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink wikiinternallink\\" lang=\\"EN-CA\\" style=\\"font-size: 10pt; font-size: 10pt\\" %\)Reference wiki>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/ECommerceFoundation/Cross\_Cutting\_Projects/2024Planning/2024\_Initiatives\]\]\(%%\)\).\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\n\(% lang=\\"EN-CA\\" style=\\"font-size:10.0pt\\" %\)\*\*1. Move off of NetScaler\*\*:\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\nMove off of NetScaler load balancers leveraging guidance provided by the ReBalance program. NetScalers will not be available in ANY new regions.\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\nThe \*\*RFE team,\*\* in collaboration with the \*\*ICON team,\*\* is driving the \[\[ReBalance program>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/ReBalance/||contenteditable=\\"false\\" title=\\"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/ReBalance/\\"\]\], which aims to deprecate NetScaler load balancer usage across the SDO services. While this task cannot be tied directly to the RF goal, the RF team is driving this through the Rebalance program. NetScaler load balancers \(LB\) is reaching EOL by the end of 2024, and the L7 team has stopped purchasing licenses. Moreover, these devices do not support current encryption methods \(TLS 1.2+\), which is against the requirement from Infosec. Because of this, NetScaler will not be available in new regions, and services using NetScaler should use alternate solutions like Tardigrade or Big Mesh load balancers.\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\n\(% lang=\\"EN-CA\\" style=\\"font-size:10.0pt\\" %\)2. \*\*Migrate off of non-expanding AWS services\*\*:\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% class=\\"MsoNoSpacing\\" style=\\"text-align:justify\\" %\)\\r\\nThe new regions to which SDO services will be migrated will not have all the AWS services available in them. These AWS services are either less used globally or on the deprecation path. The AWS team provided a list of 93 AWS services that will not be available in the new region. Any service using these unavailable AWS services needs to move away from them. RF team has published \[\[list of AWS service>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Regions/Services/#HAWSServicesnotRecommendedforSDOuse||contenteditable=\\"false\\" title=\\"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Regions/Services/#HAWSServicesnotRecommendedforSDOuse\\"\]\] those will not be available in \*\*ZAZ\*\* region and published the specific SDO services in \[\[RF analyzer dashboard>>url:https://us-east-1.quicksight.aws.amazon.com/sn/dashboards/920605f0-b871-449a-bcdd-914c6155e83e?||contenteditable=\\"false\\" title=\\"https://us-east-1.quicksight.aws.amazon.com/sn/dashboards/920605f0-b871-449a-bcdd-914c6155e83e?\\"\]\]. \\n"} [1]: \"/bin/view/Last_Mile_And_Middle_Mile/REALM/EPIC/RegionFlexibility/\" [2]: https://phonetool.amazon.com/users/hkhinda [3]: /bin/view/AmazonWiki/Permissions/UserGuide/#HHowdoIchangethePrimaryContactvalueofaWikipage3F [4]: \"/bin/view/XWiki/hkhinda\" [5]: \"/bin/view/Last_Mile_And_Middle_Mile/REALM/EPIC/RegionFlexibility/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\""},{"url":"https://broadcast.amazon.com/videos/1361959?query=Region+Flexibility+AWS&focus=title&match=Amazon+Business+Verification+Region+Flexibility","displayTitle":"Amazon Business Verification Region Flexibility","domain":"broadcast","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1733257258000,"score":0,"rank":5,"categoryList":["Amazon Business - Customer Acquisition Technology"],"body":"{"status":"error","error":"No transcript URL found in the video page."}"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/B2B/IBA/CXP/Internal_Documents/IBACXPRegionFlexibility/","displayTitle":"IBA CXP Region Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1747826105000,"score":0,"rank":6,"categoryList":["Quip2Wiki","Quip2Wiki:xhtml"],"body":" in the retail website\\n\\nLow\\n\\nNo data storage implications\\n\\nGSTStatementResolver\\n\\nVends logic for the GST curation policy for blocking/restrict non-GST products in the retail website\\n\\nLow\\n\\nNo data storage implications\\n\\nIBAStatementResolver\\n\\nVends logic for the IBA curation policy for blocking/restrict non-IBA products in the retail website\\n\\nLow\\n\\nNo data storage implications\\n\\nCOSRetailExperience\\n\\nVends the \\"Sourced From\\" message in AOD\\n\\nLow\\n\\nNo data storage implications\\n\\nPost-checkout\\n\\nIBAPostCheckoutDatapathViews\\n\\nVends post-checkout data to AB YourOrders and TNO emails\\n\\nLow\\n\\nNo data storage implications low customer impact until Amazon Business starts consuming our logic by end of Q2, 2025\\n\\nIBAOrderingGraphQLMesh-development\\n\\nVends IBA data to customer service\\n\\nMedium\\n\\nAlthough it's a simple microservice with a lambda, CSALT team may have specific guidance for region flex\\n\\n7. Recommended approach\\n\\nThe easiest way to make something region flexible is to delete it \(should this database really exist here? Is this data needed?\). This is an opportunity to innovate and address any design/architectural gaps, the less resources to regionalize, the easier it will be. \\n\\nThe recommended strategy for this is to have a planning phase to design all the possible final states for the service, it's comparisons and the necessary resources to be added/excluded, together with the risks involved. It is recommended to start from the easiest services first, learn from it and go to the next one. \\n\\nMilestone\\n\\nTask\\n\\nGoal\\n\\nDesign\\n\\nRamp up\\n\\nGet familiarized with the region flex guide\\n\\nIdentify all dependencies\\n\\nList all the dependencies \(AAA, SNS, SQS, lambdas, etc\) and clients that will be in scope for the migration\\n\\nIdentify all data storages \(internal and external\)\\n\\nList all the data base in scope for region flex\\n\\nDetermine data storage approach for region flex\\n\\nValidate the possible approaches case by cas, considering: - Access frequency- Recreation possibility- Acceptable downtime- Required latency- Consistency requirements\\n\\nIdentify integration test coverage\\n\\nIntegration tests coverage will be key for ensuring smoth launch\\n\\nService region-flex design\\n\\nDesign the possible final states for the service. This design should also capture specific configuration changes that needs to be modified to be region flex \(see Make your configurations region flexible\), and monitoring/launch strategy.The goal is not to bring low-level code, but rather answer questions from the region flex guide and align with the team so the implementation phase goes smooth\\n\\nDevelopment\\n\\nFollow region-flex guide\\n\\nImplement solution\\n\\nLaunch preparation\\n\\nCreate MCM template\\n\\nCreate a \(bar raised?\) MCM template that will include the necessary pre-flight steps covering the service's region flex launch readiness and weblab best practices with auto-rollback based on the general service's availability alarm\\n\\nPost launch\\n\\nUpdate relevant SOPs\\n\\nOncall life investment\\n\\nUpdate relevant dashboards\\n\\nOncall life investment\\n\\n8. Conclusion from the IBA meeting \\n\\nWe will perform all the action items to move away from DUB as per AB guidelines, preferring global tables over solutions unless additional latency and eventual consistency requirements does not allow it, in which cases RegionFlex data custodian guidelines should be reviewed along with 4. Considerations for data storage, case by case.\\n\\nData storage will be migrated to IBAJourneyService AWS account as per north star vision, however, any changes in the data schema will be taken as a separate OP1 item.\\n\\nFAQs\\n\\nA. What is Region Flexibility?\\n\\nThe Region Flexibility \(RF\) program is a multi-year initiative aimed at enabling SDO's businesses to operate outside of our existing \\"mega-regions\\" of IAD, DUB, and PDX. This will allow us to move traffic across AWS regions for cost-efficiency, availability, and compliance reasons without significant effort from service owners. You can find more information about the RF program on the Region Flexibility home wiki.\\n\\nB. Is there any good practices for Region Flex?\\n\\nServices should be decoupled from region-specific configurations by using full AWS region names instead of internal region names. Teams need to incorporate region flexibility considerations into their design and code review processes to identify and address region-specific dependencies. \\nInfrastructure efficiency should be prioritized through several measures:\\n\\nUpgrading capacity from Cascade Lake to Graviton\\nRetiring older instance series\\nReducing compute footprint through peak usage optimization\\nOptimizing database and storage resources \[1\] \[2\]\\nWhen implementing region flexibility, teams should:\\n\\nAddress prerequisites by removing dependencies not available in new regions\\nSet up empty stacks in new regions with updated configurations\\nGradually fill stacks with data and traffic while testing\\nClean up old stacks after migration \[1\]\\nThe approach requires considering cross-region communication latency implications and planning accordingly. \[1\] \[2\]\\n Solution uniformity should be treated as a strategy rather than a goal, recognizing that customizations can be expensive long-term. \[3\]\\n\\n Teams should prioritize data accuracy and maintain transparency in all activities to ensure trust with partners. \[3\]\\n\\nC. What is the estimated migration effort?\\n\\nBased on Region Flex analytics:\\n\\n80 hours for simple services, up to 230 hours for more complicated ones, a\\n100 hours for average services\\n200+ hours for more complicated ones\\nAssuming 50% of “effective productive time” for an SDE \(discounting meetings, reviews, oncall and other sources of distraction\), each service may take between 20 to 50 calendar days of effort.\\n\\nD. Which services are not available in certain regions?\\n\\nShared services - Infrastructure services to configure, launch, and operate service infrastructure, e.g., Apollo, Carnaval, Odin. The presence of shared services in new regions can be found here.\\nSDO infrastructure foundational services - SDO services that provide infrastructure for SDO to build their applications on top of, e.g., Datapath, Sable, G2S2, CloudAuth, and Allegiance. The presence of SDO infrastructure foundational services in new regions can be found here.\\nSDO foundational services - SDO services used by hundreds of teams across SDO, e.g., Datapath, Hex. Some of these services are not yet available in new regions \(like ZAZ\), and are in the process of being set up in the new regions. Please find their availability information here - https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Regions/Services/#HSDOInfrastructureFoundationalServices\\nE. Is it correct to assume a customer in marketplace X will use a service in region Y?\\n\\nNo, Region Flex is also about easily enabling the service in to different regions. As commented here, Amazon wants the ability to vend traffic to customer from different regions in case of sudden ordering spikes during mid-night purchases where deals/promos/prime days are ending, optimizing cost-to-serve, availability and resilience.\\n\\nF. What are all the steps to accomplish region flex?\\n\\nData Storage Implications:\\nFor DynamoDB: Follow DynamoDB Data Migration Recipes\\nFor S3: Follow S3 Migration Recipes \\nFor Aurora \(RDS\): Follow RDS Migration Recipes\\nFor external team's DDB: Coordinate with dependency teams for cross-region access\\nEvaluate each datastore for:\\nData necessity\\nAccess frequency\\nRecreation possibility\\nAcceptable downtime\\nRequired latency\\nConsistency requirements\\nLambda and Compute:\\nSet up proper IAM permissions in new region\\nImplement CloudWatch logging and monitoring\\nCreate metric filters and log scans\\nVerify function compatibility in new region\\nInfrastructure Setup:\\nCreate/extend AWS accounts to new region\\nSync AWS service quotas between regions\\nUpdate IAM roles and policies\\nImplement monitoring and alarming\\nKale Attestation:\\nRecall attestation selecting \\"EU Region Flexibility Campaign\\"\\nUpdate to include new region\\nComplete simplified three-step workf"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/SPS-RegionFlex/","displayTitle":"Region Flex for Selling Partner Services (SPS)","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1733856077000,"score":0,"rank":7,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [Region Flex for Selling Partner Services \(SPS\)][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Owner **[ wwsps-regionflexibility-wg \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n \\n \\n Last modified 8 months ago by [briahenk][3].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][4]\\n {{transclude name=\\"space:SPS-RegionFlex.Header\\"/}}\\r\\n= Region Flex for Selling Partner Services \(SPS\) =\\r\\n\\r\\n\[\[Region Flexibility>>Region\_Flexibility.\]\] is a program run by the \[\[eCommerce Foundation \(eCF\) team>>eCommerceFoundation.\]\] with the objective of enabling \[\[SDO.\]\] to easily utilize additional AWS regions for the purposes of cost-efficiency, availability, change in legal compliance requirements etc. The current focus of region flexibility is the \[\[Diversify AWS Region Usage \(DARU\) program>>CloudTune.CapacityManagementPlanning.Programs.SDODiversifyAWSRegionUsage.\]\], which aims to exit SDO from the existing IAD, PDX, and DUB \\"mega-regions\\" entirely by 2030. The Region Flexibility Engineering \(RFE\) organization is providing tooling and general guidance to teams to assist in the migration out of these regions and into new ones, as well as driving and coordinating campaigns to make services more region flexible. \\r\\n\\r\\nThis wiki is intended to supplement existing Region Flexibility guidance and documentation by providing SPS builders more specific resources and opinionated guidance both for short-term mitigations and for long-term flexibility.\\r\\n\\r\\n== Exiting DUB ==\\r\\n\\r\\nThe capacity constraints in DUB are the most pressing. Datacenter electricity usage in Ireland \[\[exceeded 14% of all usage in 2022>>https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-61308747\]\] and the local utility has \[\[imposed a moratorium on datacenter expansion through 2028>>https://www.irishtimes.com/business/2023/06/17/up-to-82-data-centres-operating-in-republic\]\]. To ensure that SDO continues to have capacity to grow and to not impact other AWS customers in the region, SDO is now committed to fully exit DUB by the end of 2026. \[\[In 2025, SPS will take a 40% DUB capacity reduction goal>>SPS-RegionFlex.Yearly.2025\]\].\\r\\n\\r\\nTo meet this 2025 goal, SPS will establish new regional instances of 1\) services that are dependencies of retail sub-experiences \(Checkout\), 2\) services that constitute 80% of SPS DUB IMR, and 3\) partner-facing Mons and SP-API applications. Each of these services will migrate relevant data and traffic to ZAZ, FRA, or both according to their \[\[routing strategy>>SPS-RegionFlex.RoutingStrategies\]\]. In 2026, SPS will complete our migration out of DUB by establishing remaining services in ZAZ and FRA, migrating remaining data out of DUB, and establishing at least a subset of services to HYD.\\r\\n\\r\\n== Other Initiatives ==\\r\\n\\r\\nIn addition to exiting DUB, SDO will need to eventually exit IAD and PDX regions. IAD will primarily require SDO services to migrate from existing AZs to new, “Holiday” AZs that are more distant than existing AZs and have higher latency. The first “Holiday” AZs will become available in 2025 and specific fleets have been contacted to migrate. SPS teams should expect to begin migrating in 2026. Migrating to the new AZs will be significantly less effort than migrating to a new region, however there is still manual work required.\\r\\n\\r\\nThe RFE team is currently considering what regions will be made available to replace PDX. Selling Partner customers would benefit from new regions being located in southeast Asia, where the majority of Selling Partners are based. We will continue to advocate that the RFE team choose regions that offer benefit to our customers while also solving capacity constraints. We currently do not have even soft commitments on new region launches after 2025 and only know ZAZ, FRA, and IAD \(Holiday\) will be available long-term. \\r\\n\\r\\nThe below table is constructed using both the RFE team's roadmap for SDO foundational services \(communicated in MBR\) and the \[\[DARU program's timeline>>https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/CapacityManagementPlanning/Programs/SDODiversifyAWSRegionUsage/\]\] for capacity reduction.\\r\\n\\r\\n\[\[image:region-guidance-table.png||width=\\"100%\\"\]\]\\r\\n\\r\\n== Mental Model ==\\r\\n\\r\\nRegions mitigate a fundamental problem in computation, which is that distance generates latency. By collocating our services in regions, we can rely on a low-latency, consistent, and reliable network. Communication between regions occurs over large distances and across multiple network providers, meaning orders of magnitude higher latency, low consistency of that latency, much lower reliability, and significantly higher costs. Software that can rely on intra-region communication is simpler to develop, easier to maintain, cheaper to run, and provides a better customer experience. Services are best deployed to multiple regions and interact with other services only within the same region.\\r\\n\\r\\nAWS currently offers 31 geographically dispersed and fault-isolated AWS regions across two AWS partitions \(‘aws’ and ‘aws-cn’\). However, only four of these regions have SDO-foundational software, such as CloudAuth, Allegiance, or OPF. SPS services are generally deployed into at least one of the three ‘aws’ partition regions: IAD \(NA / us-east-1\), DUB \(EU / eu-west-1\), and PDX \(FE / us-west-2\). RFE identifies these three regions as mega-regions. These mega-regions are fast approaching their physical capacity limits, and simply reducing each service’s footprint is not enough to ensure we have continued capacity for growth. To permanently reduce capacity in existing regions, services must be either turned off or migrated elsewhere. \\r\\n\\r\\nTo that end, the RFE team is driving the establishment of SDO-foundational software in additional regions. \*\*No single new region will exceed or even match the capacity in existing mega-regions\*\*, so instead of doing a lift and shift migration, SDO must adopt multiple new AWS regions for each existing mega-region. If we assume that DUB, IAD and PDX will each require at least two replacement regions, then SDO will likely need to adopt at least one new AWS regions each of the next 6 years. This means we need a consistent, repeatable strategy along with automation that is integrated into our existing tooling and frameworks.\\r\\n\\r\\nServices at Amazon utilize a \[\[routing strategy>>SPS-RegionFlex.RoutingStrategies\]\] to determine where a request can be processed efficiently and where data is stored. Service owners may not even know which strategy they use - most services are routed implicitly by relying on utilizing services in the same region for any given request. However, the routing strategy informs a service which regions it must utilize and when, where data must be available, and how to coordinate with consumers and dependencies. It is important that services utilize a relatively small set of routing strategies to increase in-region service alignment and reduce complexity when communicating with other services. Service owners must start by identifying and formalizing their service's choice of routing strategy in order to plan migrations. \\r\\n\\r\\n== How can I stay connected or get help? ==\\r\\n\\r\\n\* Watch out for emailed flashes and updates from \[\[wwsps-regionflexibility-core@amazon.com>>https://email-list.corp.amazon.com/email-list/expand-list/wwsps-regionflexibility-core\]\] \(pre-subscribed\)\\r\\n\* Join the SDO-wide Region Flex Slack channel \(\[\[#region-flex-2024>>https://amazon.enterprise.slack.com/archives/C05D7C8PVDY\]\]\)\\r\\n\* Join the SPS-specific Region Flex Slack channel \(\[\[#sps-region-flex>>https://amazon.enterprise.slack.com/archives/C06NN8Q8V9R\]\]\)\\r\\n\* Contact your nearest \[\[SPS Region Flex SPOC>>SPS-RegionFlex.Contact.WebHome||anchor=\\"HSPSRegionFlexSPOCs\\"\]\]\\r\\n\* Contact \(or join\) the \[\[SPS Region Flex Working Group>>SPS-RegionFlex.Contact.WebHome||anchor=\\"HSPSRegionFlexWorkingGroup\\"\]\]\\n"} [1]: \"/bin/view/SPS-RegionFlex/\" [2]: \"https://permissions.amazon.com/group.mhtml?group=wwsps-regionflexibility-wg&group_type=ldap\" [3]: \"/bin/view/XWiki/briahenk\" [4]: \"/bin/view/SPS-RegionFlex/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\""},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Users/saitejay/TechDocs/AWS/RegionFlexibilityOverview/","displayTitle":"RegionFlexibilityOverview","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1747608672000,"score":0,"rank":8,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [RegionFlexibilityOverview][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Contact **[saitejay \(user\)][2]_[ How do I change this value?][3]_\\n \\n \\n Last modified 2 months ago by [saitejay][4].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][5]\\n {{transclude name=\\"awsui.beta\\"/}}\\n{{toc/}}\\n\\n---\\n\\n# AWS Region Flexibility Overview\\n\\nDate: 2025-05-15\\nStatus: #reference\\nTags: #aws #region-flexibility #lra #migration\\n\\n## What is Region Flexibility?\\n\\nRegion Flexibility is an AWS initiative to ensure services can operate across multiple AWS regions and migrate between regions with minimal disruption. This initiative is particularly important as AWS plans to exit certain \\"mega-regions\\" \(IAD, DUB, PDX\) over the next 6 years, with some migrations beginning as early as 2024.\\n\\n## Key Components\\n\\n### 1. Local Region Affinity \(LRA\)\\n\\nLRA provides region-agnostic \`\*.lra.amazon\` endpoints that resolve to regional endpoints based on the caller's region. This abstraction allows services to migrate between regions without requiring coordination with their callers.\\n\\n\*\*Benefits:\*\*\\n- Decouples service location from service discovery\\n- Enables seamless region migrations\\n- Reduces cross-region traffic\\n- Improves latency by routing to the closest available endpoint\\n\\n\*\*Implementation:\*\*\\n- Services register their regional endpoints with LRA\\n- DNS resolution maps LRA endpoints to appropriate regional endpoints\\n- Callers use the LRA endpoint instead of specific regional endpoints\\n\\nFor detailed implementation steps, see \[\[LRA Implementation Guide\]\].\\n\\n### 2. Service Migration\\n\\nThe process of moving a service from one AWS region to another, which includes:\\n\\n- Infrastructure deployment in the new region\\n- Data migration or replication\\n- Traffic shifting\\n- Decommissioning old infrastructure\\n\\n### 3. Region Compatibility\\n\\nEnsuring services use AWS features and services that are available in all target regions. This includes:\\n\\n- Avoiding region-specific services\\n- Using services with multi-region support\\n- Addressing deprecated services \(like SimpleDB\)\\n\\n## Current Region Exit Timeline\\n\\n| Region | Code | Exit Deadline | Status |\\n|--------|------|--------------|--------|\\n| Dublin | DUB | EOY 2026 | Active exit planning |\\n| US East | IAD | ~2028 | Early planning |\\n| US West | PDX | ~2029 | Early planning |\\n\\n## Common Region Flexibility Risks\\n\\n1. \*\*Deprecated Service Usage\*\*\\n - Services like SimpleDB that won't be available in new regions\\n - Legacy AWS services with no migration path\\n\\n2. \*\*Missing LRA Endpoints\*\*\\n - Services not vending LRA endpoints\\n - Blocking dependent services from region migration\\n\\n3. \*\*Hard-coded Regional Endpoints\*\*\\n - Services with hard-coded regional endpoints in their code\\n - Configuration that assumes specific regions\\n\\n4. \*\*Cross-Region Dependencies\*\*\\n - Services that depend on resources in specific regions\\n - Synchronous cross-region calls\\n\\n## Remediation Approaches\\n\\n### For Deprecated Services\\n\\n1. \*\*Migration to Supported Alternatives\*\*\\n - SimpleDB → DynamoDB\\n - Legacy services → Current generation services\\n\\n2. \*\*Service Removal\*\*\\n - Decommissioning unused services\\n - Archiving historical data\\n\\n### For LRA Onboarding\\n\\n1. \*\*Endpoint Registration\*\*\\n - Creating LRA configurations\\n - Updating certificates\\n\\n2. \*\*Client Updates\*\*\\n - Modifying client packages to use LRA endpoints\\n - Updating configuration in Brazil Config or Coral Config\\n\\n### For Hard-coded Endpoints\\n\\n1. \*\*Configuration Externalization\*\*\\n - Moving endpoints to configuration\\n - Implementing dynamic endpoint resolution\\n\\n2. \*\*Service Discovery\*\*\\n - Using service discovery mechanisms\\n - Implementing fallback logic\\n\\n## Tools and Resources\\n\\n- \*\*Mechanic CLI\*\*: For LRA configuration and testing\\n- \*\*Region Flexibility Analyzer\*\*: Identifies region flexibility issues\\n- \*\*Policy Engine\*\*: Tracks and enforces region flexibility compliance\\n- \*\*Shepherd\*\*: Risk management for region flexibility issues\\n\\n## Related Oncall Activities\\n\\n- \[\[Work/Oncall/LRA Onboarding Oncall Activity\]\]\\n- \[\[Work/Oncall/SimpleDB Region Flexibility Risk Remediation\]\]\\n\\n## Related Documentation\\n\\n- \[\[LRA Implementation Guide\]\] - Detailed guide for implementing LRA\\n\\n## References\\n\\n- \[Region Flexibility Wiki\]\(https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/\)\\n- \[LRA Documentation\]\(https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Local%20Region%20Affinity/\)\\n- \[Region Exit Timeline\]\(https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Timeline/\)\\n- \[Migration Playbooks\]\(https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Playbooks/\)\\n\\n"} [1]: \"/bin/view/Users/saitejay/TechDocs/AWS/RegionFlexibilityOverview/\" [2]: https://phonetool.amazon.com/users/saitejay [3]: /bin/view/AmazonWiki/Permissions/UserGuide/#HHowdoIchangethePrimaryContactvalueofaWikipage3F [4]: \"/bin/view/XWiki/saitejay\" [5]: \"/bin/view/Users/saitejay/TechDocs/AWS/RegionFlexibilityOverview/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\""},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/BuyerRiskPrevention/CrossCutting/RegionFlexibility/","displayTitle":"Region Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1741202512000,"score":0,"rank":9,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [Region Flexibility][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Owner **[ brp-org-all \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n \\n \\n Last modified 5 months ago by [psperez][3].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][4]\\n {{transclude name=\\"space:BuyerRiskPrevention.BRPTemplate\\"/}}\\n\\n= Region Flexibility =\\n\\n== Executive Summary ==\\n\\nAmazon's Region Flexibility \(RF\) and Diversify AWS Region Usage \(DARU\) Cross Cutting Initiative \(CCI\) is an Amazon wide and Campaign Category I strategic program to decentralize operations from mega-region \(DUB, IAD, PDX\). For Buyer Risk Prevention \(BRP\), in 2025 this involves migrating critical systems across Payment Risk, Account Integrity, and Abuse Prevention from DUB to new regions: Zaragoza \(ZAZ\) and Frankfurt \(FRA\) with the goal to fully exit DUB by 2026. The goal is to improve resilience, meet evolving regulatory requirements, and enhance customer experience.\\n\\n== Program Goals and Timelines ==\\n\\n\*\*Goal 1: Be prod ready for sub-experience \(BRP is part of cart/checkout and identity\) traffic migration\*\* by 7/31 \(UK/SP marketplaces to ZAZ\) and 8/15 \(DE marketplace to FRA\).\\n\\n\*\*Goal 2: Achieve a 40% IMR costs Reduction in DUB\*\* by 10/16/2025. The bigger needle movers are the Bring Your Own Account fleets which have CORE owned service holding BRP data, we own those fleets for accounting purposes. We will also ensure that we leaving a manageable effort scope to fully exit DUB on 2026.\\n\\n== Migration Approach and Challenges ==\\n\\nRegion Flexibility team decided to perform the traffic switch in phases to reduce the complexity and risk by selecting sub-experiences \(customer experience on Amazon web page that can be migrated mostly independently\) and specific market places on 2025. BRP is only affected by cart/checkout and identity sub-experiences and we need to be ready for traffic switch by 7/31 \(ZAZ\) and 8/15 \(FRA\) for cart/checkout and 8/15 \(ZAZ\) and 8/31 \(FRA\) for identity. All the other marketplaces will remain in DUB until 2026, therefore this means the involved services will need to support traffic in DUB, ZAZ, and FRA during that period.\\n\\nMany of our services are highly dependent on CORE team to run our fraud evaluations, we are working very closely with them to ensure their systems are ready by 6/15 \(or earlier\) to allow at least 6 weeks of service testing. We have agreed with CORE to replicate all the data in each region when necessary to avoid any fraud detection capabilities regression and only performing cross-region calls otherwise. If the BRP service is not latency sensitive, you can call CORE service or any other dependency not yet available on ZAZ/FRA with a cross region call which will add around 30ms with peaks of 65ms.\\n\\nWe are working on a ML testing strategy to ensure that all the intents are well tested and have parity with current DUB performance before any traffic switch.\\n\\n== Tech Strategy ==\\n\\nWe are working on a tech strategy document which will include BRP specific SOP to guide BRP service migration. We are currently reviewing the document with leadership and we will share it here when done. ETA 3/15.\\n\\n== Mitigation Strategies ==\\n\\n\*\*Risk 1: Resource and Sequencing Challenges\*\* BRP's Region Flexibility efforts can encounter risk due to overlapping priorities, competing initiatives, and peak workloads.\\n\\n\*\*Risk 2: Data, Latency, and Model Performance Risks\*\* Decentralizing data and ML models across regions poses risks to fraud detection accuracy, latency, and data availability.\\n\\n\*\*Risk 3: External to BRP Dependency Risks\*\* BRP's success depends on robust mechanisms to monitor dependencies, escalate risks, and maintain alignment with teams like CARML and URES.\\n\\n== Key Points of Contact ==\\n\\n\(% style=\\"width:942px\\" %\)\\n|=\(% style=\\"width: 163px;\\" %\)Role Area|=\(% style=\\"width: 157px;\\" %\)Overall BRP|=\(% style=\\"width: 130px;\\" %\)Payment Risk|=\(% style=\\"width: 178px;\\" %\)Account Integrity|=\(% style=\\"width: 127px;\\" %\)Buyer Abuse|=\(% style=\\"width: 127px;\\" %\)ML|=\(% style=\\"width: 119px;\\" %\)CORE\\n|\(% style=\\"width:163px\\" %\)\*\*STL\*\*|\(% style=\\"width:157px\\" %\)psperez@|\(% style=\\"width:130px\\" %\)psperez@|\(% style=\\"width:178px\\" %\)shisrame@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)psperez@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)planfeng@|\(% style=\\"width:119px\\" %\)prdeepn@\\n|\(% style=\\"width:163px\\" %\)\*\*Tech\*\*|\(% style=\\"width:157px\\" %\)gabeprz@|\(% style=\\"width:130px\\" %\)ritikaj@|\(% style=\\"width:178px\\" %\)bradcamp@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)torbettp@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)chienluc@|\(% style=\\"width:119px\\" %\)prdeepn@\\n|\(% style=\\"width:163px\\" %\)\*\*Senior Leadership\*\*|\(% style=\\"width:157px\\" %\)ujjwalm@|\(% style=\\"width:130px\\" %\)rajks@|\(% style=\\"width:178px\\" %\)ajat@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)mrbohl@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)xiaohus@|\(% style=\\"width:119px\\" %\)gddesai@\\n\\n== Office Hours ==\\n\\nWe have weekly BRP Region Flexibility office hours with our Sr SDEs and ML PoCs. Sign up below and we will add you to the call. Please, attend at the time of the slot selected \(10:00 am or 10:15 am\). If you think the topic will take more than 15 minutes, sign up for both slots, please be intentional when taking both slots as there is limited time for the whole BRP org.\\n\\n\*\*How to sign up\*\*\\nAdd your Team/aliases under Team/Owner, the topic/question you would like to discuss under Topic, what kind of support you are seeking including your preference for Abuse/AIT/PRE Sr SDE \(depending on your org ask\) and/or ML by the day before \(Wed\) at 2:00pm. We will forward the meeting to the aliases on Team/Owner by Wed.\\n\\n|=\(% style=\\"width: 87px;\\" %\)Day|\(% style=\\"width:114px\\" %\)Time|=\(% style=\\"width: 139px;\\" %\)Team/Owner|=\(% {"content":{"results":[{"url":"https://ui.rfe.amazon.dev","body":"The Region Flexibility Portal assists SDO teams in planning their region flexibility migrations.","displayTitle":"Region Flexibility Portal (SDO)","domain":"tool","resultType":"document","resultId":"ea7f3836-14de-4674-8e14-a8705f26f269","modificationDate":1739997681532,"interestGroup":null,"resourceType":null,"status":"production","documentationUrl":null,"ownerList":null,"sageTagList":null,"score":59.47095,"ownedByAmazon":true,"sourceCodeUrl":null,"rank":0,"categoryList":[]},{"url":"https://reflex.realm.amazon.dev","body":"ReFlex MaX provides a streamlined self-service automated workflow for SDO teams to migrate MAWS to new efficient capacity types. Service owners can use this tool at any point of their infrastructure set up ( build, host ordering, scaling, descaling and clean-up) while also providing the ability to monitor progress through completion of the DARU initiative.","displayTitle":"ReFlex MaX","domain":"tool","resultType":"document","resultId":"46f414bd-afc9-4872-90e1-958d2a292778","modificationDate":1743435496905,"interestGroup":"https://email-list.corp.amazon.com/email-list/expand-list/deltatools-interest","resourceType":null,"status":"production","documentationUrl":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Last_Mile_And_Middle_Mile/REALM/Trans_DevOps/Tool_Development/ReFlex_MaX/","ownerList":["TEAM$Squid-Team"],"sageTagList":null,"score":51.6397,"ownedByAmazon":true,"sourceCodeUrl":"https://code.amazon.com/packages/SquidUIServiceWebsite","rank":1,"categoryList":[]},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/IN-Region-Flexibility/","displayTitle":"IN Region Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1740419757000,"score":0,"rank":1,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [IN Region Flexibility][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Owner **[ in-region-flexibility \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n \\n \\n Last modified 5 months ago by [paparaoc][3].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][4]\\n {{transclude name=\\"INRegionFlexibility\\"/}}\\r\\n\\r\\n{{comment}}\\r\\n The template for the IN Regional Flexibility wiki can be found at https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Templates/INRegionFlexibility/\\r\\n{{/comment}}\\r\\n\\r\\n{{container cssClass=\\"floatinginfobox\\"}}\\r\\n\\r\\n\(% border=\\"1\\" %\)\\r\\n|\(% style=\\"border-right:2.5px solid #00004d; border-left:2.5px solid #00004d; padding-right:25px; padding-left:25px; width:30%\\" %\)\(\(\(\\r\\n\\r\\n{{toc/}}\\r\\n\\r\\n== Problem Scope ==\\r\\nOver the next 18-24 months the Stores, Devices, and Other \(SDO\) organization will move 25%+ of our OLTP data across AWS regions to provide operational flexibility and overcome scaling constraints for our existing and new marketplace expansion. Region flexibility is an SDO led initiative aimed at simplifying the efforts to get SDO services rapidly into new or existing AWS regions to address operational and regulatory challenges. Since 2020, SDO has been investing in components of regional flexibility by enabling technologies: Service Configuration Discovery and Routing \(Axon, Almanac, Veritas, Planisphere, others\), Data analysis \(Metador, Andes, others\) and movement \(Hotwire/LMT, GlobeMaster, CDMS\). While these investments allowed us to address specific pain points, Service/Application owners \(Builders\) are required to assemble these services to build out and execute a migration recipe that meets their need and addresses constraints. What is missing is a guided, friction-less customer experience or unified solution for Builders to orchestrate \(fully/semi-automated or manual\) migrations that addresses dependencies, run time latency needs, and shared data access constraints, while still keeping their business running.\\r\\n\\r\\nAs an example, the Region Flexibility team may want to stand up \(all\) the necessary services for an experience in a new region, then migrate the data necessary for the experience incrementally and atomically \(e.g. such that all the data for a specific customer appears in the new region together\). This requires understanding the services' upstream and downstream dependencies, along with the computational views that the services consume. It also requires orchestrating data movement to aid functional debugging, validation, and auditing. Doing these migrations without coordination will be resource intensive for application owners and builders.\\r\\n\\r\\n== Our Vision ==\\r\\nEnable SDO's businesses to operate outside of our existing \\"mega-regions\\" of IAD, DUB, and PDX; and enable the movement of traffic across AWS regions for the purposes of cost-efficiency, availability, change in legal compliance requirements etc. without effort from the service owner. The North Star for region flexibility is to centrally deploy services to new or expanding regions and move data and customer traffic between regions in a matter of months without negatively impacting service owners or customers. In short, most service owners should not need to know where their systems and data reside.\\r\\n\\r\\nThe IN Region Flexibility team's charter focuses on three core objectives: 1\) Execute DARU S-Team Goal compliance and facilitate DUB exit for IES by EOY 2026; 2\) Drive IES services to be 100% region flexible with optimal investments and overall org productivity enhancements; and 3\) Develop robust region and data migration tooling via strategic collaboration with WW Region Flex Engineering \(RFE\) and Managed Migration Experience \(M2X\) organizations. \\r\\n\\r\\nThe IN Region Flexibility team owns UI console and Testing Framework in this initiative and is responsible for establishing new solutions and architectural patterns in these fields to help services owners get into regions more quickly, in partnership with different teams at Amazon.\\r\\n\\r\\n== Program Overview ==\\r\\nhttps://w.amazon.com/bin/view/IN-Region-Flexibility/Overview/\\r\\n\\r\\n== Tenets ==\\r\\n\\r\\n\[TBD\]\\r\\n\\r\\n== Architecture ==\\r\\n\\r\\n\[\[image:https://maxis-file-service-prod-dub.dub.proxy.amazon.com/issues/cabe9f31-df17-4958-8ff5-d2aaa7c6e548/attachments/e693b07c32ba24ff14c5674857d1681c8cf20e973beca1924f7bc6db881c4c26\_1b2ac41c-af1a-46f2-9b72-1b0990552717||width=\\"50%\\"\]\]\\r\\n\\r\\n\*\*Coordinator\*\* is an umbrella service which contains various different services/component. It is an orchestration service that delegates the entire migration process to various tools and components. These various tools and components will also depend on what type of migration a customer wants to perform.\\r\\n\\r\\n\*\*MetaDor\*\* is the the component that will power the discovery experience over the MetaData UI console. MetaDor will be the source of information for getting information required to enable migrations on service/dataset level. These informations will be used to prepare migration entity, MODs and MEDs.\\r\\n\\r\\n\*\*DRA\*\* is the component which will keep track of status of entities under migration and enable in routing traffic to proper region.\\r\\n\\r\\n\*\*Data Movement Services\*\* is the component which will actually move the data, i.e, perform migration. It will also provide capabilities to Coordinator to start/stop/terminate migration at Dataset/service level. One of the example if this service is CDMS which is is a suite of data movement solutions for SDO data owners who need to move their data across AWS regions, partitions, accounts and storage technologies.\\r\\n\\r\\nThe detailed architecture for the entire Region Flexibility program can be found here https://broadcast.amazon.com/channels/64990/videos.\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n== Related Terminologies ==\\r\\nhttps://quip-amazon.com/G2aSAoR1EpHr/M2X-Domain-Terminology\\r\\n\\r\\n== LEADERSHIP ==\\r\\n\\r\\n{{transclude name=\\"HyperBadge\\" args=\\"\\r\\n |username=anupkr\\r\\n Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1684112380000,"score":0,"rank":2,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [Region Flexibility][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Owner **[ sps-tech-pmo \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n \\n \\n Last modified 2 years ago by [sssrid][3].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][4]\\n {{transclude name=\\"CARML.TechPMO\\"/}}\\n\\n{{toc numbered=\\"true\\"/}}\\n\\n= Region Flexibility Program Overview =\\n\\nRegion Flexibility refers to Amazon’s ability to run its businesses by utilizing compute capacity from a growing set of AWS regions. This gives Amazon more options to bring functionality closer to customers, leverage compute supply across wider geographies, and in certain cases like Enfield, comply with data privacy legislation. There are a growing set of important and timely reasons for SDO to be able to operate across a wider set of AWS regions than we do today. To accomplish this, SDO must be able to move data and software with much more agility across AWS regions.\\n\\nIn 2022, Region Flexibility Program\(% style=\\"--original-color:#16191f; color:#16191f\\" textcolor=\\"#16191f\\" %\) team partnered with SDO teams for a series of \(%%\)\*\*Investigations \*\*\(% style=\\"--original-color:#16191f; color:#16191f\\" textcolor=\\"#16191f\\" %\)into areas that will be important or problematic for region flexibility, but where there is no good idea of a path forward. These investigations resulted in new ideas for \(%%\)\*\*Accelerators\*\*\(% style=\\"--original-color:#16191f; color:#16191f\\" textcolor=\\"#16191f\\" %\) \(projects that will speed up the work teams have to do, or reduce the likelihood of manual error\) and \(%%\)\*\*Enablers\*\*\(% style=\\"--original-color:#16191f; color:#16191f\\" textcolor=\\"#16191f\\" %\) \(projects required to make migration feasible, often by reducing cross-team coordination\).\(%%\) Region Flexibility teams asked SDO teams to contribute in building the Enablers and Accelerators \(EAs\) in 2023.\\n\\n== What's New for 2023? ==\\n\\nIn 2023, WW SPS teams planned to allocate 8 HC to work in resource loaner model on Regional Flexibility Enablers and Accelerators Projects. These 8 HC will be working on these 3 EAs \(1\) Safe Rules Rollout, \(2\) Run Test Migrations, and \(3\) Eliminate need for ClientConfig to support a realm before calls can be started. \\n\\n= 2023 Goals & Mechanisms =\\n\\n== 2023 Goals ==\\n\\n{{html}}\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n \\r\\n\\r\\n
#Goal LevelGoal DescriptionOwnerKingpin ID
1eLTLaunch Almanac as a plug-in to BigMesh Proxy to enable ubiquitously available request routing capabilities across all SDO services regardless of underlying service framework/languagealbrown@, bshukman@, brandal@, micklos@632324
2eLTShift test data and traffic for three SDO domain entities residing in Sable between two regions by using a prototype of the Managed Migration eXperience \(M2X\)jhorak@565187
