In this catalyst sprint, we are looking to drive Application Modernization revenue, specifically EKS both for our ISV and SI partners. The ‘EKS ISV to SI Co-Sell motion’ is our answer to addressing four themes observed from customers, partners, and field interactions; 1/Customers prioritize working with System Integrators \\(SIs\\) that can provide end-to-end solutions \\(software and services\\) to help our them build new digital experiences with cloud-native applications on AWS, 2/SIs are 'pressured' to differentiate their application modernization consulting or managed services offerings to increase profitability per customer or contract, 3/Independent Software Vendors \\(ISVs\\) have limited resources to market, sell, or deploy their solutions due its focus on building innovative software/solutions \\[CloudHedge, Rafay System, and Aqua Security are examples of ISVs with System Integrators-focused GTM as part of their 2023 partner plans\\], and finally, 4/AWS teams are already 'brokering' intros between ISVs and SIs, but in an //'ad-hoc'// fashion with low success rate where this Catalyst sprint can become the scalable \\(introductory\\) mechanism. \\*\\*The goal of this co-sell sprint is to drive awareness of 'vetted' solutions from AWS ISVs \\(e.g., Competency/Service Ready Partners\\) and foster higher levels of collaboration between these software and service paths partners as they plan to integrate offerings and joint GTM motions. As this will focus on ISV and SI partners focused on EKS, this Co-Sell motion will help to drive EKS revenue. We are looking for both ISV and SI partners based in EMEA to drive this motion.\\*\\* Participation in this sprint will provide current ISV and SI pairs with customer visibility as well as avenues to drive co-sell with additional SI and ISVs. Sprint starts/started in May 2023. Storage volumes behave like raw, unformatted block devices, with user supplied device names and a block device interface. Customers can create a file system on top of Amazon EBS volumes, or use them in any other way they would use a block device \\(like a hard drive\\). Amazon EBS volumes are network-attached, and persist independently from the life of an instance with an annual failure rate \\(AFR\\) >url:https://app.smartsheet.com/b/form/aeadf03bd9bc4d0b96afaa3adb76de99\\]\\].\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n= \\(% style=\\\\\"font-family:Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif; font-size:16px\\\\\" %\\)\\*\\*Flexible Compute Sprint for APJ \\(ANZ / ASEAN / India\\) SIs starting March 2023\\*\\*\\(%%\\) =\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\(% style=\\\\\"text-align: left;\\\\\" %\\)\\\\r\\\\n\\(% style=\\\\\"font-family:Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif; font-size:16px\\\\\" %\\)\\[\\[Flexible Compute>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Teams/TFC/Compute/FocusAreas/FlexibleCompute/\\]\\] consists of architectural best practices and specific AWS Services that optimize and improve performance of customer workloads while minimizing waste, and reducing costs through sizing, scaling, and flexibility. Services include AWS Auto Scaling, \\[\\[EC2 Spot>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/spot/\\]\\] & \\[\\[Graviton>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/pm/ec2-graviton\\]\\] processors. With a global recession looming, cost optimization is high on the agenda for the majority of our customers heading into 2023. Cost savings is more than dollars and cents. Cost optimization gives customers agility to \\(a\\) respond better to competition or disruption \\(e.g. an economic down turn\\) and can free up resources to invest back into their business to innovate faster or \\(b\\) scale fast and stay within budget on short-term projects. \\*\\*We are looking to partner with motivated SI or MSP’s with existing Graviton Service Designations or those helping customers with optimization of their workloads. \\*\\*Participation in the sprint will provide benefits like 1:1 enablement on technical and business value proposition of Flexible compute services, POC cash/credits and opportunity for lead sharing for key Partners. Sprint starts/started in March 2023. Outposts supports workloads and devices requiring low latency access to on-premises systems, local data processing, data residency, and application migration with local system interdependencies. Outposts solutions allow you to extend and run native AWS services on premises, and is available in a variety of form factors, from 1U and 2U \\[\\[Outposts server>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/outposts/servers/\\]\\]s to 42U Outposts racks, and multiple rack deployments. With AWS Outposts, customers can run some AWS services locally and connect to a broad range of services available in the local AWS Region. AWS Built-In addresses this issue by validating 3rd party packages that are able to install, configure, and integrate with AWS native services for a full featured experience without requiring additional resources. \\\\n      # Wiki source code of [TMEGS Resilience Core Team Newsletter 11/15/2024][1]\n\\\\n    \\\\n        \\\\n              **Primary Owner **[ es-tmegs-resilience-security-core-team \\(LDAP\\) ][2]\\\\n          \\\\n                                                                      \\\\n        Last modified 6 months ago by [lok][3].\\\\n      \\\\n      \\\\n  \\\\n---\n\\\\n  \\\\n name=\\\\\"space:TMEGS-Resilience-Security-CoreTeam.Templates.NavBar-Template\\\\\"/}}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n{{toc/}}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n{{box}}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\(% style=\\\\\"align:center\\\\\" %\\)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Introduction ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWelcome to the latest edition of our TMEGS Resilience Newsletter! In this issue, we'll explore recent updates, best practices, and insights to help you build more resilient applications and infrastructure on AWS. Whether you're new to AWS or a seasoned pro, you'll find valuable information to enhance your cloud resilience strategy.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Service Updates ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[AWS Fault Injection Service now generates experiment reports>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/11/aws-fault-injection-service-experiment-reports/\\]\\] 11/12/2024\\\\r\\\\nAWS Fault Injection Service now generates experiment reports, providing evidence of resilience testing and application response for easier evaluation and compliance.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[EC2 Auto Scaling introduces provisioning control on strict availability zone balance>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/11/ec2-auto-scaling-strict-availability-zone-balance/\\]\\] 11/8/2024\\\\r\\\\nAmazon EC2 Auto Scaling Groups now provide customers greater control over strict availability zone balancing for EC2 instance provisioning without the need of custom code to override ASG’s default behaviors.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[AWS Incident Detection and Response now available in 16 additional AWS regions>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/11/aws-incident-detection-response-16-additional-aws-regions/\\]\\] 11/1/2024\\\\r\\\\nAWS Incident Detection and Response expands to 16 additional regions, offering 24/7 expert support for incident management and workload resilience to Enterprise Support customers.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[AWS Lambda now supports AWS Fault Injection Service \\(FIS\\) actions>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/10/aws-lambda-fault-injection-service-actions/\\]\\] 10/30/2024\\\\r\\\\nAWS Lambda now supports AWS Fault Injection Service \\(FIS\\) actions, allowing developers to test and improve application resilience by simulating various fault scenarios without code modifications.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[Announcing the new Resiliency widget on myApplications>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/10/resiliency-widget-myapplications\\]\\] 10/22/2024\\\\r\\\\nThe new Resiliency widget on myApplications provides enhanced visibility and control over application resilience, allowing users to initiate assessments and view actionable insights directly from the dashboard.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Best Practices ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== How an insurance company implements disaster recovery of 3-tier applications ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:1732295849256-121.png||height=\\\\\"671\\\\\" width=\\\\\"1286\\\\\"\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n//The Pilot Light scenario for a 3-tier application that has application servers and a database deployed in two Regions//\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\This blog discusses how a US-based insurance company implemented a disaster recovery strategy for their critical 3-tier applications using AWS services. The company needed a solution for their Java and .Net applications that use various database engines running on Amazon EC2 instances.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\The company's requirements included implementing a Pilot Light or Warm/Standby scenario, keeping costs low, allowing for manual failover, and maintaining a Recovery Time Objective \\(RTO\\) and Recovery Point Objective \\(RPO\\) under 15 minutes. They also needed to avoid using public resources.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\To meet these requirements, the company designed a solution encompassing both failover and failback scenarios. The failover process uses AWS services like EventBridge, Lambda functions, and Jenkins pipelines to detect issues and initiate the failover. It includes manual approval steps and uses Route53 for traffic redirection. The failback process, which returns operations to the primary region, is initiated manually by an operator. It involves database synchronization, manual approval steps, and a careful process to switch back to the primary region.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\The company's approach demonstrates their commitment to business continuity and resilience. By tailoring the architecture to their specific needs, they've created a solution that not only meets their technical requirements but also aligns with their internal processes and operating model. This solution offers several benefits, including customizability, standardization across different technologies, achievement of the desired RPO and RTO, and cost optimization through the use of cloud-native services.\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[Read the full article>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/architecture/how-an-insurance-company-implements-disaster-recovery-of-3-tier-applications/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== TMEGS Customers Case Study ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Sportradar delivers cloud-native OTT \\(over-the-top\\) on AWS ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:1732295849030-241.png||height=\\\\\"100\\\\\" width=\\\\\"600\\\\\"\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\nSportradar, a global sports technology company, has successfully transitioned its over-the-top \\(OTT\\) streaming service to a cloud-native architecture on Amazon Web Services \\(AWS\\). This transformation was driven by the need to meet growing demand for low-latency global streaming capabilities, high availability, scalability and resiliency needs of their customers.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\Key points:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. Sportradar's migration to AWS occurred in two phases: first to a hybrid on-premises/AWS setup, then to a fully cloud-native AWS infrastructure. The move resulted in a 30% reduction in costs and improved availability through multi-availability zone redundancy.\\\\r\\\\n1. Sportradar adopted a serverless cloud computing environment using services like AWS CloudFormation, Amazon ECS with AWS Fargate, and Amazon S3. Benefits of the cloud-native architecture include high scalability, flexibility to handle sudden traffic spikes, and improved performance.\\\\r\\\\n1. Monitoring and observability were enhanced using Amazon CloudWatch and Amazon OpenSearch Service.\\\\r\\\\n1. The new setup allows Sportradar to stream both sporting events and non-sporting events like concerts with high quality and reliability.\\\\r\\\\n1. The migration has enabled Sportradar to meet the high availability, scalability, and resiliency needs of their customers in the fast-growing OTT services industry.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis case study demonstrates how AWS can help media companies modernize their streaming infrastructure to meet increasing demands in the OTT market.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[Read the full case study>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/media/sportradar-delivers-cloud-native-ott-on-aws/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Recent Resilience Blog Posts ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Strengthen application resilience with myApplications and AWS Resilience Hub ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:1732295850535-558.png||height=\\\\\"720\\\\\" width=\\\\\"1280\\\\\"\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis blog post introduces the integration of AWS Resilience Hub with the myApplications feature in the AWS Management Console, offering a streamlined approach to managing and enhancing application resilience. The integration allows users to automatically create and update applications in AWS Resilience Hub based on myApplications constructs, trigger resilience assessments, and monitor results directly in the AWS Management Console. It provides a consolidated view of key application metrics, including resilience, security, cost, and performance.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\The post outlines the process of setting up and assessing an application's resilience, explains the metrics displayed in the new Resilience widget, and offers best practices for maximizing the benefits of this integration. This solution simplifies cloud management, strengthens application resilience, and helps organizations maintain a comprehensive understanding of their applications' security, resilience, and compliance posture.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[Read the full article>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/mt/strengthen-application-resilience-with-myapplications-and-aws-resilience-hub/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Resilience webinars ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nAWS Resilience EBC - \\*\\*November 21st, 2024 \\*\\*\\\\r\\\\nInvite your customers to the \\*\\*AWS Resilience EBC in NYC \\*\\*for TMEGS customers\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*Dates: Thu, Nov 21, 2024\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*Time: 12:00 PM - 5:00 PM\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*Office Location: JFK27\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*Register\\*\\* now and secure your spot: \\[\\[https:~~/~~/aws-experience.com/amer/smb/e/9b2c5/new-york-architecture-resilience-day.>>url:https://quip-amazon.com/D56SAy9AOqLN/TMEGS-ME-EBC-Nominations-NYC-Nov-21st-2024\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[School of Resiliency>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/School\\_of\\_Resilience/Content\\]\\] \\*\\*\\(Review wiki for full upcoming sessions’ date/time\\)\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\nThe School of Resilience’s primary mission is to become a reference program that provides ongoing education, training and awareness about resilience related matters across Amazon internal stakeholders. Even though several initiatives exist around the subject of resilience - i.e. Resilience TFC, Resilience Labs, AWS Well-Architected principles, etc. - customers and the AWS field have manifested the need to provide more in-depth training and general awareness on designing for resilience from the ground up, with a more structured curricula and in a more programmatic and structured manner.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n|Location|Date|Registration Link|Status\\\\r\\\\n|VIRTUAL / ONLINE - NAMER CDT \\(US Central time zone\\)|December 11^^th^^ and 12^^th^^, 2024|\\[\\[https:~~/~~/tiny.amazon.com/1h4n6h1cy/atozamazworkleariltevenTEVL>>url:https://tiny.amazon.com/1h4n6h1cy/atozamazworkleariltevenTEVL\\]\\]|Fully online, required to be on-camera.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Resilience training and workshop ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Programs ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[Resilience Core Program \\(RCP\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/AGSTech/WWT/Resilience/ResilienceCoreProgram/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe \\*\\*Resilience Core Program \\(RCP\\)\\*\\* is a joint engagement between customer and AWS teams to review the resilience controls \\(detective, preventive, recovery and testing\\) of a user journey delivered by a customer critical application.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[Driving Resilience: Planning - Execution - Testing \\(Dr. PET\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Teams/TAM/DrivingResilience/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*Dr PET\\*\\* //\\(spelled 'doctor pet'\\)// is an SME facilitated engagement process for Enterprise Support customers to review their Resiliency Readiness requirements and to provide proactive guidance to help address any gaps.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[Simulated Conditions Response and Management \\(SCRaM\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/SCRAM/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nSCRaM is a tabletop exercise for a specific AWS workload to determine and enhance its readiness to handle a specific scenario.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[AWS Resilience Hub for ES \\(ARH\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Teams/TAM/ARHEnablementforESCustomers/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nARH enables Enterprise Support \\(ES\\) customers to proactively prepare and protect against disruptions, thereby improving their overall resilience posture by utilizing Resilience Hub.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Trainings and Hands On Workshops ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Customer School of Resilience \\(CSoR\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/School\\_of\\_Resilience/Customer\\_School\\_of\\_Resilience/Home/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Customer Chaos GameDay \\(Continuous Resilience through Chaos Engineering \\(CR/CE\\) Program\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Teams/Technical\\_Feedback\\_Communities/Resilience/Focus\\_Groups/Chaos%20Engineering/Program\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Resilience Immersion Day>>url:https://immersionday.com/resilience-immersionday\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Well-Architected Labs on Disaster Recovery>>url:https://wellarchitectedlabs.com/reliability/disaster-recovery/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Disaster Recovery on AWS Labs>>url:https://disaster-recovery.workshop.aws/en/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Resilience Workshops>>url:https://workshops.aws/categories/Resilience\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Introduction to AWS Resilience Hub>>url:https://explore.skillbuilder.aws/learn/course/external/view/elearning/14679/introduction-to-aws-resilience-hub\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nProfessional Services - Pro-Serve Engagements\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Resilient Application Readiness Assessment>>url:https://pmt.amazonaws.com/offerings/resilient-application-readiness-assessment-for-financial-services\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery Accelerator>>url:https://pmt.amazonaws.com/offerings/a2db110d-fd94-4909-81b7-81f2806ef356\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Conclusion ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nAs we've seen in this newsletter, AWS continues to innovate and provide new tools and services to enhance the resilience of your cloud infrastructure.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\Remember, building resilient systems is an ongoing process. We encourage you to stay updated on the latest AWS resilience practices and continuously test and improve your architectures. For more information, visit the \\[\\[AWS Resilience Hub>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/resilience-hub/\\]\\] and subscribe to the AWS Blog for regular updates.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\Thank you for reading, and here's to building more resilient cloud solutions!\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n \\\\n\"}\n[1]: \\\"/bin/view/TMEGS-Resilience-Security-CoreTeam/Content/Newsletters/Nov15/\\\"\n[2]: \\\"https://permissions.amazon.com/group.mhtml?group=es-tmegs-resilience-security-core-team&group_type=ldap\\\"\n[3]: \\\"/bin/view/XWiki/lok\\\"\n[4]: \\\"/bin/view/TMEGS-Resilience-Security-CoreTeam/Content/Newsletters/Nov15/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\\\""},{"url":"https://apg-library.amazonaws.com/content/9e3921cb-dc05-4bcd-8b74-327ece96fbbd","displayTitle":"AWS Cost Reduction Strategies","domain":"apgl","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1739979728102,"score":0,"rank":9,"categoryList":["Strategy","CostManagement","CloudFoundations","BusinessProductivity"],"body":"...and <em>cost</em> <em>optimization</em>. toolUseResult.text: {"content":{"results":[{"url":"https://broadcast.amazon.com/videos/1361959?query=Region+Flexibility+benefits+cost+optimization+resilience+scaling&focus=title&match=Amazon+Business+Verification+Region+Flexibility","displayTitle":"Amazon Business Verification Region Flexibility","domain":"broadcast","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1733257258000,"score":0,"rank":1,"categoryList":["Amazon Business - Customer Acquisition Technology"],"body":"{\"status\":\"error\",\"error\":\"No transcript URL found in the video page.\"}"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Teams/Sales-BD/Alliances/catalyst_initiative/team/nominate/","displayTitle":"Nominate A Partner","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1738357860000,"score":0,"rank":2,"categoryList":[],"body":"end users. Remote teams and complex distributed systems combined with the increase need for frequent releases mean an organization and its systems need to be more resilient than ever. As with security at AWS, ownership of resilience falls under a shared responsibility model: AWS is responsible for resilience of the cloud, while customers are responsible for resilience of their workloads in the cloud. Customers globally have asked AWS to help reduce the burden on them to meet their resilience in the cloud responsibilities with a standardized framework with actionable roadmaps they can phase into their unique AWS environments. We will soon launch a\\[\\[ Resilience Competency Program>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/APN\\_Cloud\\_Foundations/Resilience\\]\\] \\(AWS internal wiki link\\) that will help Partners market and differentiate their business to AWS customers by showcasing their skills in this specialized area. Attaining an AWS Competency will help services path and software path Partners market and differentiate their business to AWS customers by showcasing their skills in this specialized area. Partners can apply to one or more of the following categories 1/ Highly Available and Resilient Architecture Design \\(Services Path\\), 2/ Resilient Application Design and Development \\(Services Path\\), 3/ Chaos Engineering and Resilience Testing \\(Software and Services Path\\), 4/ 24X7 Observability and Monitoring \\(Software and Services Path\\), 5/Operations and Incident management \\(Software and Services Path\\), 6/Business continuity and Disaster Recovery \\(Software and Services Path\\) and 7/ Core Resilience \\(Services Path\\). This Catalyst sprint provides an opportunity for select software and services path Partners to start/complete this designation prior to official public launch! Participation in this sprint will provide the partner with 1:1 enablement, support navigating the program, open up several GTM benefits, and set them up to be an early Resilience Competency Partner! Sprint starts/started in May 2023. \\*\\*Partner nominations now closed.\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== \\*\\*Guardduty Sprint\\*\\* ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== \\*\\*Geo:\\*\\* EMEA \\*\\*Category:\\*\\* SI \\*\\*Timeline:\\*\\* May 2023 through November 2023 ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWith Amazon Guardduty, AWS customers will have the capability to detect and response to threats, and drive compliance assessments when consuming Amazon Elastic Container Service for Kubernetes \\(EKS\\). Currently, customers use a combination of Amazon Elastic Container Service \\(ECS\\), AWS Fargate services, and ISV solutions. With addition of new features, we can provide deeper functionality to our Partners. In this sprint, we will work with SI Partners, enable them on these new features, so they can incorporate them onto their offering. We will support SI Partners create Sales Packages, help them create opportunities, and drive other co-sell motions. Sprint starts/started in May 2023. \\*\\*Partner nominations now closed.\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n= \\*\\*Compute and Storage Services\\*\\* =\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== \\*\\*EBS SAN Migration Sprint\\*\\* ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== \\*\\*Geo:\\*\\* NAMER \\*\\*Category:\\*\\* ISV/SI \\*\\*Timeline:\\*\\* March 2023 through September 2023 ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[Amazon Elastic Block Store \\(EBS\\)>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/ebs/\\]\\] provides block level storage volumes for use with Amazon EC2 instances. Storage volumes behave like raw, unformatted block devices, with user supplied device names and a block device interface. Customers can create a file system on top of Amazon EBS volumes, or use them in any other way they would use a block device \\(like a hard drive\\). Amazon EBS volumes are network-attached, and persist independently from the life of an instance with an annual failure rate \\(AFR\\) >url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Teams/TFC/Compute/FocusAreas/FlexibleCompute/\\]\\] consists of architectural best practices and specific AWS Services that optimize and improve performance of customer workloads while minimizing waste, and reducing costs through sizing, scaling, and flexibility. Services include AWS Auto Scaling, \\[\\[EC2 Spot>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/spot/\\]\\] & \\[\\[Graviton>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/pm/ec2-graviton\\]\\] processors. With a global recession looming, cost optimization is high on the agenda for the majority of our customers heading into 2023. Cost savings is more than dollars and cents. Cost optimization gives customers agility to \\(a\\) respond better to competition or disruption \\(e.g. an economic down turn\\) and can free up resources to invest back into their business to innovate faster or \\(b\\) scale fast and stay within budget on short-term projects. We are looking to Partner with motivated SI or MSP’s with existing Graviton Service Designations or those helping customers with optimization of their workloads. Participation in the sprint will provide benefits like 1:1 enablement on technical and business value proposition of Flexible compute services, POC cash/credits and opportunity for lead sharing for key Partners. Sprint starts/started in March 2023. \\*\\*Partner nominations now closed.\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n= \\*\\*Connect and Contact Center Services\\*\\* =\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== \\*\\*Amazon Connect Sprint\\*\\* ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== \\*\\*Geo:\\*\\* KOREA \\*\\*Category:\\*\\* SI \\*\\*Timeline:\\*\\* February 2023 through August 2023 ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[Amazon Connect>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/pm/connect\\]\\] is a Contact Centre as a Service \\(CCaaS\\) solution provided by AWS that allows customers \\(ranging from Enterprise to SMB\\) to design and deliver truly innovative customer experiences \\(CX\\). There are a growing number of associated services included in the Amazon Connect ecosystem, including \\[\\[Contact Lens>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/connect/contact-lens/\\]\\] \\(sentiment analysis\\), \\[\\[Wisdom>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/connect/wisdom/\\]\\] \\(knowledge management\\) etc. This Partner GTM activity will be focused in Korea, a key market to drive Connect adoption through Partners. We will focus on market entry motions to supercharge onboarding and market traction of Korean Partners. We are seeking to work with existing Partners who have \\[\\[Connect Service Delivery Program>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/directconnect/partners/\\]\\] validation, along with other Partners who have capability to deliver Contact Centre and those who can integrate offerings from the Connect Ecosystem, or Partners who have capability with other CC solutions. During the Sprint, Partners will have the opportunity receive specialist support to enhance their technical and GTM capabilities. Partners who create a connect offering can also participate in joint demand generation activities. Sprint starts/started in February 2023. \\*\\*Partner nominations now closed.\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n= \\*\\*Database Services\\*\\* =\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== \\*\\*Database Migration Accelerator Sprint\\*\\* ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== \\*\\*Geo:\\*\\* EMEA \\*\\*Category:\\*\\* ISV/SI \\*\\*Timeline:\\*\\* January 2023 through July 2023 ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMigrating applications and databases can be time consuming and technically challenging as the engineers working on these migrations require in-depth knowledge of both the source and target databases, as well as various programming frameworks. As a result, traditional migration projects frequently run over budget or are delayed. AWS offers \\[\\[Amazon Database Migration Accelerator \\(DMA\\)>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/solutions/databasemigrations/database-migration-accelerator/\\]\\], a solution that brings together \\[\\[AWS Database Migration Service \\(DMS\\)>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/dms/\\]\\], \\[\\[AWS Schema Conversion Tool \\(SCT\\)>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/dms/schema-conversion-tool/#:~~:text=WQF%20uses%20AWS%20Schema%20Conversion,them%20to%20an%20AWS%20database.\\]\\], and AWS database experts to help customers migrate away from traditional commercial databases at fixed prices. Amazon DMA supports migrations from Oracle or SQL Server to \\[\\[Amazon Aurora>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/rds/aurora/\\]\\], or \\[\\[Amazon Relational Database Service \\(RDS\\)>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/rds/\\]\\] for PostgreSQL and MySQL. Amazon DMA allows customers to pay after the migration is complete thereby reducing the risk of cost overruns and leverages the technical learnings from \\[\\[Amazon’s experience>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/solutions/case-studies/amazon-database-migration/\\]\\] in migrating its internal systems to AWS database ser"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/FlexibleCompute/EC2CapacityGuidelinesAndBestPractices/CustomerEngagementPlaybook/","displayTitle":"CustomerEngagementPlaybook","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1692880002000,"score":0,"rank":3,"categoryList":[],"body":"{\"status\":\"success\",\"content\":\"\\\\n  \\\\n                    \\\\n      # Wiki source code of [CustomerEngagementPlaybook][1]\n\\\\n    \\\\n        \\\\n              **Primary Owner **[ cmrtint-team \\(LDAP\\) ][2]\\\\n          \\\\n                                                                      \\\\n        Last modified 1 year ago by [jossaq][3].\\\\n      \\\\n      \\\\n  \\\\n---\n\\\\n  \\\\n    \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n  [Show line numbers][4]\\\\n  {{transclude name=\\\\\"space:FlexibleCompute.Templates.FCCITemplate\\\\\" args=\\\\\"TITLE= Capacity Best Practices | SUBTITLE=Customer Engagement Playbook \\\\\"/}}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n{{toc start=\\\\\"2\\\\\"/}}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf you’re here, you may be working with a customer who has a capacity requirement for a specific instance type/s in a particular region/AZs. Your customer could be: \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* Migrating to a new instance generation \\(e.g. C5 → C6\\) or to a new architecture \\(e.g. x86 → Graviton-based instance\\) \\\\r\\\\n\\* Migrating a mid-to-large scale workload from on-prem/another cloud provider to AWS or between regions \\\\r\\\\n\\* Launching a new workload or expanding into a new AZ or region \\\\r\\\\n\\* Experiencing business growth that is leading to accelerated usage and results in a new EC2 usage profile \\(e.g. growing from 10 instances per week to 100\\) \\\\r\\\\n\\* Planning a one-time scale-up requirement \\(e.g. load testing, etc.\\)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis engagement playbook helps you help customers avoid experiencing challenges when pursuing their desired capacity. On the whole, customers will rarely experience insufficient capacity, and as you enable your customers on the following capacity and flexibility concepts, it is important to highlight to your customers that they will enhance their elasticity by tailoring their scaling strategies to their workloads. If their workload can tolerate multiple instance families across multiple AZs, only requesting one instance type or one AZ will naturally limit your customer’s maximum accessible capacity. AWS provides a ton of capacity; oftentimes the unnecessary limits of your customers’ inflexibility prematurely imposes a capacity challenge. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Engagement Playbook Contents ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. Engagement Model – Capacity Planning with Customers \\\\r\\\\n1. EC2 Capacity Concepts \\\\r\\\\n1. EC2 Flexibility Concepts \\\\r\\\\n1. Workload Profiles\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Engagement Model - Capacity Planning with Customers ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:https://w.amazon.com/bin/download/FlexibleCompute/EC2CapacityGuidelinesAndBestPractices/CustomerEngagementPlaybook/WebHome/CapManSuccess.png?\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. Understand the customer’s workload requirements. Ask questions to understand the customer’s objectives and workload requirements. Whether a customer is planning a small or large-scale migration, it is important to understand their expectations on: instance types/sizes, quantity, preferred regions/AZs, purchasing models, usage pattern \\(steady-state or elastic\\), and timelines. \\\\r\\\\n11. Start with the Capacity Planning Qualification Guide\\\\r\\\\n11. Here is the Accelerated Compute Qualification Guidance\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n2. \\*\\*Assess and educate on general EC2 capacity concepts and the Benefits of Flexibility.\\*\\* Part of the customer planning process is education. Customers do not always understand that they should consider balancing performance with availability. Though these are not mutually exclusive, there are times when pursuing the optimal instance for the workload my increase their likelihood of encountering insufficient capacity. To mitigate that risk, customers should consider how they can tap into more capacity pools while still prioritizing workload performance. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== EC2 Capacity Concepts ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*//Why do customers experience capacity challenges?//\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nCustomer’s sometimes, though rarely, experience insufficient capacity exceptions \\(ICE\\) because the demand for a given capacity pool may, albeit temporarily, exceed the available capacity in that pool. We purchase capacity based on customer demand for that capacity pool; the capacity planning team \\(CCX\\) models what they need based on historic pool utilization, and, combined with direct customer capacity signals \\(i.e., FOOB\\), procures capacity accordingly. Each capacity pool has different needs. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nDespite the low likelihood that your customers will encounter capacity difficulties, your customers need to build for resilience and elasticity. The more flexible customers are in the way they run workloads, the more likely they are to ensure application uptime and the less likely they are to encounter insufficient capacity exceptions \\(ICE\\). \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWe provide the following capacity and flexibility concepts to help you understand how to equip your customers, but if I could distill capacity guidance down to a key concept, it mostly comes down to the “capacity pool”, i.e., a set of instances of a given type, within a particular region and Availability Zone. If your customer is ICE’ed, that means that one or a number of requested capacity pools did not have their desired capacity. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n==== Key EC2 capacity concepts: ====\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*Capacity Pool\\*\\* - a set of instances of a given type, within a particular region and Availability Zone\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* Every instance type \\(e.g., r5.8xlarge, p3.2xlarge, etc.\\) and generation \\(e.g., c4 vs c5\\) across every AZ is its own capacity pool that is maintained independently. \\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* Capacity pools fluctuate based on customer demand for that pool, and grows according to demand thresholds and forecasted organic growth. \\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* Having flexibility to use multiple instance types and/or AZs expands the number of capacity pools available for your workload and improves likelihood that the customer’s capacity requirements will be consistently met.\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*\\* E.g., if an instance type is unavailable in one AZ, it could still be available in the other AZs within a given region.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*Capacity Management\\*\\* - For AWS, this means balancing supply and demand to ensure the optimal capacity pool usage \\(i.e., not overbuying or underbuying capacity for a given pool\\). For customers, this means efficiently adding and using EC2 capacity. \\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[\\(% class=\\\\\"wikiinternallink\\\\\" %\\)\\*\\*FOOB or Assisted Capacity Reservation \\(ACR\\)\\*\\*>>https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/EC2\\_Capacity\\_Planning/Customer\\_Planning\\_Group/Customer\\_Planning\\_Resources/AWS-Assisted\\_CR\\]\\]\\(%%\\) - FOOB stands for \\\\\"Future Out Of Band\\\\\" signal. FOOBs are used to communicate to EC2 that there is an emergent or spiky customer demand event that is not predicted by the past behavior of the customer.\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*\\[\\[On-Demand Capacity Reservations \\(ODCR\\)>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-capacity-reservations.html\\]\\] \\*\\*- ODCRs enable you to reserve compute capacity for your Amazon EC2 instances in a specific Availability Zone for any duration. Capacity Reservations mitigate against the risk of not getting On-Demand capacity in the rare chance that capacity is not available. If you have very strict capacity requirements and are running a business critical workload, either long term or short, we recommend that you create a capacity reservation to ensure you always have access to EC2 capacity when you need it, for as long as you need it.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n==== EC2 Flexibility Concepts ====\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n===== Benefits of Flexibility =====\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nAs stated above, a customer is ICE’d when there is not enough capacity available in the requested capacity pool\\(s\\). The more capacity pools into which you can scale, the more likely you are to get what you request. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWhen booking a flight, you are less likely to get a seat if you are only willing to take 1A, or Row 1, or an exit row. Each time you widen the conditions, you expand your ability to get a seat on the plane. It’s also easier to book a flight if you’re willing to fly at lower demand dates and times. Each of these \\(e.g., seats, rows, dates/times, etc.\\) are variables you can adjust to increase your likelihood of getting a flight.\\\\r\\\\nYour customers need to understand that part of building for resilience is optimizing for availability, i.e., enabling their application to use as many capacity pools as possible. This means adjusting instance type/family, AZs, and Regions \\(see “flexibility pyramid” below for simplicity\\). \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*Key Benefits of having EC2 flexibility:\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* Access to more capacity\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* More instance types and more regions/AZs = more accessible capacity pools for the workload\\\\r\\\\n\\* Better elasticity\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* Ability to scale up and scale down without encountering insufficient capacity errors \\(ICEs\\), and improved price/performance benefits as customers more optimally manage their capacity with automated scaling functions \\(i.e., ASG, etc.\\)\\\\r\\\\n\\* Better balancing of price and performance\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* Price benefits of On Demand \\(and Spot!\\): customers can continue to run their workloads on On Demand and even Spot as they introduce flexibility into their scaling practices. They don’t have to pay for what they don’t use by holding and/or reserving capacity to ensure they have it.\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* Reduced cost of waiting for capacity due to inflexibility\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nA simple way to identify your customers’ potential areas of improvement will be to walk them through the three principal categories of flexibility. If your customer can flex on even one of these categories they are likely to see marked improvement in their ability to obtain their needed capacity. The pyramid is not intended to be a sequential process, so much as to demonstrate three logical categories of variables customers have at their disposal to increase availability. The base of the pyramid simply shows the categories with the most variables, while the top has fewer levers to improve availability. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nKnowledge is Power!!! Did you know you can set priority instance types and, in the case of ICEs, automagically scale across mixed instance types/purchase options and based on \\[\\[attributes>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/create-asg-instance-type-requirements.html\\]\\] or \\[\\[desired instance mix>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/ec2-auto-scaling-mixed-instances-groups.html\\]\\]? \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:https://w.amazon.com/bin/download/FlexibleCompute/EC2CapacityGuidelinesAndBestPractices/CustomerEngagementPlaybook/WebHome/Ec2FlexP.png\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. Instance\\\\r\\\\n11. Instance Types \\(m5.24xlarge, r5.12xlarge, c6i.2xlarge, etc.\\)\\\\r\\\\n11. Instance Families \\(C5, M5, R5\\)\\\\r\\\\n111. Generations \\(C3, C4, C5\\) \\\\r\\\\n11. Compute Architecture \\(i.e., Intel, AMD, ARM\\)\\\\r\\\\n111. Availability differs across compute architectures, which underscores the need for flexibility here, especially when using lower availability options. \\\\r\\\\n1. Geography\\\\r\\\\n11. Availability Zones \\(AZs\\)\\\\r\\\\n11. Regions\\\\r\\\\n1. Time\\\\r\\\\n11. Run workloads on nights/weekends or when capacity returns following ICE’d requests \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nFor a refresher on Pricing Models, Instance Types and Geography, review the following:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[EC2 Pricing Models>>https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/pricing/\\]\\] \\(Spot, On-Demand, and Savings Plans\\)\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[EC2 Instance Types>>https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/\\]\\] \\(e.g. General / Accelerated\\)\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[EC2 Regions and Availability Zones>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-regions-availability-zones.html\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n==== Capacity Management Products ====\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nSometimes, despite providing the above guidance regarding improving flexibility to improve customer access to availability, a customer’s flexibility limitations may warrant moving beyond On Demand use to On Demand Capacity Reservations \\(ODCRs\\) that enable customers to reserve their target capacity. If a customer requires some level of capacity assurance, they should consider \\[\\[creating an ODCR>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/capacity-reservations-using.html\\]\\]. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n==== Capacity Assurance Cheat Sheet ====\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:https://w.amazon.com/bin/download/FlexibleCompute/EC2CapacityGuidelinesAndBestPractices/CustomerEngagementPlaybook/WebHome/CapCheatSheet.png\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n==== AWS Scaling Practices – Improving Flexibility ====\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWe’ve detailed a quick list of top items to consider when customers are building their applications to diversify across the aforementioned availability variables as they scale. For more detail visit Optimizing EC2 for Cost and Capacity, which includes resources on AWS Auto Scaling, EC2 Spot and other AWS purchase options. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nQuick Reference:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* Be flexible about instance types, Availability Zones and even Regions \\\\r\\\\n\\* Use \\[\\[EC2 Auto Scaling groups \\(ASG\\)>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/auto-scaling-groups.html\\]\\] to manage your desired capacity\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* Use \\[\\[Attribute-based Instance Selection \\(ABIS\\)>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/create-asg-instance-type-requirements.html\\]\\] to enhance your pursuit of instance availability \\\\r\\\\n\\*\\* Scale across \\[\\[multiple instance types/purchase options>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/ec2-auto-scaling-mixed-instances-groups.html\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\* Use \\[\\[EC2 Fleet>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-fleet.html\\]\\] or \\[\\[EC2 ASG>>https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/auto-scaling-groups.html\\]\\] to manage your target capacity \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*Workload Profiles \\(Work in Progress\\):\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\nA wealth manager assesses your risk profile and determines your asset mix. You lower your risk through efficient diversification of assets. Similarly, your customers’ workloads have varying tolerance to performance/downtime on the one hand, and price on the other. Customers can reduce their price/downtime risk through diversification across instance types/family, geo, time, purchase options, reservations, etc. A lower risk workload can use EC2 Spot, for example, reducing their overall price, even as interruptions may reduce performance \\(i.e., lower potential uptime\\). Higher risk workloads, i.e., mission critical workloads, may be better served with On Demand Capacity Reservations \\(ODCRs\\), which increases the overall price to hold the instance, but reduces the risk of downtime \\(i.e., through ICEs\\). We try to detail a few common workloads you may face and provide high-level guidance on how to help customers mediate between price, performance and availability. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*Spiky Workloads \\(Embarrassingly Parallel\\)\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\nThe maximum amount of time a customer can run an instance 24/7 or 100% of the time \\(e.g., database workloads, etc.\\). A spiky workload is a workload that runs for multiple time durations that do not equal 100%. A VFX firm can run render workloads or allocate workstations, or perhaps an automotive company can run nightly autonomous vehicle software regression tests, for 10hrs/weekday totalling 50hrs/week \\(or 30% of the time\\). If a customer needs capacity assurance for these workloads \\(i.e., they won’t get ICE’d when they need to scale\\), AWS suggests obtaining an ODCR. This means you pay for 24/7 use when you only have 10/7 use. Assurance increases the cost of compute.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n \\\\n\"}\n[1]: \\\"/bin/view/FlexibleCompute/EC2CapacityGuidelinesAndBestPractices/CustomerEngagementPlaybook/\\\"\n[2]: \\\"https://permissions.amazon.com/group.mhtml?group=cmrtint-team&group_type=ldap\\\"\n[3]: \\\"/bin/view/XWiki/jossaq\\\"\n[4]: \\\"/bin/view/FlexibleCompute/EC2CapacityGuidelinesAndBestPractices/CustomerEngagementPlaybook/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\\\""},{"url":"https://broadcast.amazon.com/videos/844627?query=Region+Flexibility+benefits+cost+optimization+resilience+scaling&focus=title&match=Region+Flexibility%3A+Why%2C+when%2C+and+what+it+means+for+2024%2C+The+Edge%2C+ep+145","displayTitle":"Region Flexibility: Why, when, and what it means for 2024, The Edge, ep 145","domain":"broadcast","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1736981513000,"score":0,"rank":4,"categoryList":["The Edge","Region Flexibility"],"body":"s some of the top asks that our engineers have about region flex, Lisa Tread. Uh,\",\"tim"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Main/CatalystNomination/","displayTitle":"CatalystNomination","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1676306238000,"score":0,"rank":5,"categoryList":[],"body":" =\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\(% style=\\\\\"text-align: left;\\\\\" %\\)\\\\r\\\\n\\(% style=\\\\\"font-family:Arial,Helvetica,sans-serif; font-size:16px\\\\\" %\\)\\[\\[Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service \\(EKS\\)>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/eks/\\]\\] provides managed container orchestration for customer that need to meet regulatory and data sovereignty requirements with a hybrid platform to run high-performance, data-intensive containerized workloads across on premises, cloud, and edge use cases. In this catalyst sprint, we are looking to drive Application Modernization revenue, specifically EKS both for our ISV and SI partners. The ‘EKS ISV to SI Co-Sell motion’ is our answer to addressing four themes observed from customers, partners, and field interactions; 1/Customers prioritize working with System Integrators \\(SIs\\) that can provide end-to-end solutions \\(software and services\\) to help our them build new digital experiences with cloud-native applications on AWS, 2/SIs are 'pressured' to differentiate their application modernization consulting or managed services offerings to increase profitability per customer or contract, 3/Independent Software Vendors \\(ISVs\\) have limited resources to market, sell, or deploy their solutions due its focus on building innovative software/solutions \\[CloudHedge, Rafay System, and Aqua Security are examples of ISVs with System Integrators-focused GTM as part of their 2023 partner plans\\], and finally, 4/AWS teams are already 'brokering' intros between ISVs and SIs, but in an //'ad-hoc'// fashion with low success rate where this Catalyst sprint can become the scalable \\(introductory\\) mechanism. \\*\\*The goal of this co-sell sprint is to drive awareness of 'vetted' solutions from AWS ISVs \\(e.g., Competency/Service Ready Partners\\) and foster higher levels of collaboration between these software and service paths partners as they plan to integrate offerings and joint GTM motions. As this will focus on ISV and SI partners focused on EKS, this Co-Sell motion will help to drive EKS revenue. We are looking for both ISV and SI partners based in EMEA to drive this motion.\\*\\* Participation in this sprint will provide current ISV and SI pairs with customer visibility as well as avenues to drive co-sell with additional SI and ISVs. Sprint starts/started in May 2023. Customers can create a file system on top of Amazon EBS volumes, or use them in any other way they would use a block device \\(like a hard drive\\). With AWS Outposts, customers can run some AWS services locally and connect to a broad range of services available in the local AWS Region. %\\)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Introduction ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWelcome to the latest edition of our TMEGS Resilience Newsletter! In this issue, we'll explore recent updates, best practices, and insights to help you build more resilient applications and infrastructure on AWS. Whether you're new to AWS or a seasoned pro, you'll find valuable information to enhance your cloud resilience strategy.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Service Updates ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[AWS Fault Injection Service now generates experiment reports>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/11/aws-fault-injection-service-experiment-reports/\\]\\] 11/12/2024\\\\r\\\\nAWS Fault Injection Service now generates experiment reports, providing evidence of resilience testing and application response for easier evaluation and compliance.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[EC2 Auto Scaling introduces provisioning control on strict availability zone balance>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/11/ec2-auto-scaling-strict-availability-zone-balance/\\]\\] 11/8/2024\\\\r\\\\nAmazon EC2 Auto Scaling Groups now provide customers greater control over strict availability zone balancing for EC2 instance provisioning without the need of custom code to override ASG’s default behaviors.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[AWS Incident Detection and Response now available in 16 additional AWS regions>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/11/aws-incident-detection-response-16-additional-aws-regions/\\]\\] 11/1/2024\\\\r\\\\nAWS Incident Detection and Response expands to 16 additional regions, offering 24/7 expert support for incident management and workload resilience to Enterprise Support customers.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[AWS Lambda now supports AWS Fault Injection Service \\(FIS\\) actions>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/10/aws-lambda-fault-injection-service-actions/\\]\\] 10/30/2024\\\\r\\\\nAWS Lambda now supports AWS Fault Injection Service \\(FIS\\) actions, allowing developers to test and improve application resilience by simulating various fault scenarios without code modifications.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[Announcing the new Resiliency widget on myApplications>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/10/resiliency-widget-myapplications\\]\\] 10/22/2024\\\\r\\\\nThe new Resiliency widget on myApplications provides enhanced visibility and control over application resilience, allowing users to initiate assessments and view actionable insights directly from the dashboard.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Best Practices ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== How an insurance company implements disaster recovery of 3-tier applications ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:1732295849256-121.png||height=\\\\\"671\\\\\" width=\\\\\"1286\\\\\"\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n//The Pilot Light scenario for a 3-tier application that has application servers and a database deployed in two Regions//\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\This blog discusses how a US-based insurance company implemented a disaster recovery strategy for their critical 3-tier applications using AWS services. The company needed a solution for their Java and .Net applications that use various database engines running on Amazon EC2 instances.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\The company's requirements included implementing a Pilot Light or Warm/Standby scenario, keeping costs low, allowing for manual failover, and maintaining a Recovery Time Objective \\(RTO\\) and Recovery Point Objective \\(RPO\\) under 15 minutes. They also needed to avoid using public resources.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\To meet these requirements, the company designed a solution encompassing both failover and failback scenarios. The failover process uses AWS services like EventBridge, Lambda functions, and Jenkins pipelines to detect issues and initiate the failover. It includes manual approval steps and uses Route53 for traffic redirection. The failback process, which returns operations to the primary region, is initiated manually by an operator. It involves database synchronization, manual approval steps, and a careful process to switch back to the primary region.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\The company's approach demonstrates their commitment to business continuity and resilience. By tailoring the architecture to their specific needs, they've created a solution that not only meets their technical requirements but also aligns with their internal processes and operating model. This solution offers several benefits, including customizability, standardization across different technologies, achievement of the desired RPO and RTO, and cost optimization through the use of cloud-native services.\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[Read the full article>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/architecture/how-an-insurance-company-implements-disaster-recovery-of-3-tier-applications/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== TMEGS Customers Case Study ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Sportradar delivers cloud-native OTT \\(over-the-top\\) on AWS ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:1732295849030-241.png||height=\\\\\"100\\\\\" width=\\\\\"600\\\\\"\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\nSportradar, a global sports technology company, has successfully transitioned its over-the-top \\(OTT\\) streaming service to a cloud-native architecture on Amazon Web Services \\(AWS\\). This transformation was driven by the need to meet growing demand for low-latency global streaming capabilities, high availability, scalability and resiliency needs of their customers.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\Key points:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. Sportradar's migration to AWS occurred in two phases: first to a hybrid on-premises/AWS setup, then to a fully cloud-native AWS infrastructure. The move resulted in a 30% reduction in costs and improved availability through multi-availability zone redundancy.\\\\r\\\\n1. Sportradar adopted a serverless cloud computing environment using services like AWS CloudFormation, Amazon ECS with AWS Fargate, and Amazon S3. Benefits of the cloud-native architecture include high scalability, flexibility to handle sudden traffic spikes, and improved performance.\\\\r\\\\n1. Monitoring and observability were enhanced using Amazon CloudWatch and Amazon OpenSearch Service.\\\\r\\\\n1. The new setup allows Sportradar to stream both sporting events and non-sporting events like concerts with high quality and reliability.\\\\r\\\\n1. The migration has enabled Sportradar to meet the high availability, scalability, and resiliency needs of their customers in the fast-growing OTT services industry.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis case study demonstrates how AWS can help media companies modernize their streaming infrastructure to meet increasing demands in the OTT market.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[Read the full case study>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/media/sportradar-delivers-cloud-native-ott-on-aws/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Recent Resilience Blog Posts ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Strengthen application resilience with myApplications and AWS Resilience Hub ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\[\\[image:1732295850535-558.png||height=\\\\\"720\\\\\" width=\\\\\"1280\\\\\"\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis blog post introduces the integration of AWS Resilience Hub with the myApplications feature in the AWS Management Console, offering a streamlined approach to managing and enhancing application resilience. The integration allows users to automatically create and update applications in AWS Resilience Hub based on myApplications constructs, trigger resilience assessments, and monitor results directly in the AWS Management Console. It provides a consolidated view of key application metrics, including resilience, security, cost, and performance.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\The post outlines the process of setting up and assessing an application's resilience, explains the metrics displayed in the new Resilience widget, and offers best practices for maximizing the benefits of this integration. This solution simplifies cloud management, strengthens application resilience, and helps organizations maintain a comprehensive understanding of their applications' security, resilience, and compliance posture.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[Read the full article>>url:https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/mt/strengthen-application-resilience-with-myapplications-and-aws-resilience-hub/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Resilience webinars ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nAWS Resilience EBC - \\*\\*November 21st, 2024 \\*\\*\\\\r\\\\nInvite your customers to the \\*\\*AWS Resilience EBC in NYC \\*\\*for TMEGS customers\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*Dates: Thu, Nov 21, 2024\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*Time: 12:00 PM - 5:00 PM\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\*\\*Office Location: JFK27\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*Register\\*\\* now and secure your spot: \\[\\[https:~~/~~/aws-experience.com/amer/smb/e/9b2c5/new-york-architecture-resilience-day.>>url:https://quip-amazon.com/D56SAy9AOqLN/TMEGS-ME-EBC-Nominations-NYC-Nov-21st-2024\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\[\\[School of Resiliency>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/School\\_of\\_Resilience/Content\\]\\] \\*\\*\\(Review wiki for full upcoming sessions’ date/time\\)\\*\\*\\\\r\\\\nThe School of Resilience’s primary mission is to become a reference program that provides ongoing education, training and awareness about resilience related matters across Amazon internal stakeholders. Even though several initiatives exist around the subject of resilience - i.e. Resilience TFC, Resilience Labs, AWS Well-Architected principles, etc. - customers and the AWS field have manifested the need to provide more in-depth training and general awareness on designing for resilience from the ground up, with a more structured curricula and in a more programmatic and structured manner.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n|Location|Date|Registration Link|Status\\\\r\\\\n|VIRTUAL / ONLINE - NAMER CDT \\(US Central time zone\\)|December 11^^th^^ and 12^^th^^, 2024|\\[\\[https:~~/~~/tiny.amazon.com/1h4n6h1cy/atozamazworkleariltevenTEVL>>url:https://tiny.amazon.com/1h4n6h1cy/atozamazworkleariltevenTEVL\\]\\]|Fully online, required to be on-camera.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n== Resilience training and workshop ==\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Programs ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[Resilience Core Program \\(RCP\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/AGSTech/WWT/Resilience/ResilienceCoreProgram/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe \\*\\*Resilience Core Program \\(RCP\\)\\*\\* is a joint engagement between customer and AWS teams to review the resilience controls \\(detective, preventive, recovery and testing\\) of a user journey delivered by a customer critical application.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[Driving Resilience: Planning - Execution - Testing \\(Dr. PET\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Teams/TAM/DrivingResilience/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\*\\*Dr PET\\*\\* //\\(spelled 'doctor pet'\\)// is an SME facilitated engagement process for Enterprise Support customers to review their Resiliency Readiness requirements and to provide proactive guidance to help address any gaps.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[Simulated Conditions Response and Management \\(SCRaM\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/SCRAM/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nSCRaM is a tabletop exercise for a specific AWS workload to determine and enhance its readiness to handle a specific scenario.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\* \\[\\[AWS Resilience Hub for ES \\(ARH\\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/AWS/Teams/TAM/ARHEnablementforESCustomers/\\]\\]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nARH enables Enterprise Support \\(ES\\) customers to proactively prepare and protect against disruptions, thereby improving their overall resilience posture by utilizing Resilience Hub.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n=== Trainings and Hands On Workshops ===\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1. \\[\\[Customer \\n  \\n    \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n  [Show line numbers][5]\\n  == Overview ==\\r\\n\\r\\nSDO’s use of cloud capacity has historically been centered on a few key AWS “mega-regions”: DUB \(eu-west-1/Ireland\), IAD \(us-east-1/Virginia\), and PDX \(us-west-2/Oregon\). SDO’s growth in these regions has reached a point where we can no longer assume unconstrained growth in future years. Not addressing these constraints will result in business and customer impact for SDO such as pausing marketplace expansions, eliminating peak deal events, and hinder ability to execute emergent scaling due to unanticipated customer behavior. Based on the S-team alignment from Q4’23, SDO is now committed to fully exit DUB by the end of 2026 and PDX by the end of 2029, with per-year capacity reductions that meet AWS’ supportable footprint targets in these regions. This CCI is focused on leading SDO’s effort to fully Exit DUB. IAD and PDX capacity assurance efforts do not require CCI currently, but this stance will be evaluated on a yearly basis. In 2025, SDO aims to reduce its forecasted peak footprint in DUB by 40% through migrations and deprecations, including reductions in EC2 and non-EC2 capacity. All SDO services hosted in DUB must complete mandatory architecture upgrades that unblock and reduce effort of region migrations. Teams should also complete recommended architectural upgrades to improve its services region flexibility. For more details please refer to \[\[RFE wiki>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/CCI/2025/\]\].\\r\\n\\r\\n== Goal ==\\r\\n\\r\\nBy 10/31/2025, Amazon Payments will reduce server usage in DUB by 40% from the baseline established by RFE. There are 2 sub-goals \(1\) For services supporting checkout use-cases, be production ready in ZAZ by 6/30 and FRA by 8/30 \(2\) Services moving from DUB to ZAZ are migrated by 10/30/2025.\\r\\n\\r\\n== Scorecard ==\\r\\n\\r\\nComing Soon!!\\r\\n\\r\\n== Reference Documents ==\\r\\n\\r\\n\[\[Payment Services Migration Technical Strategy and Guidelines>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Payments\_Services/DARU-2025/TechStrategy\]\]\\r\\n\\r\\n\[\[AP Service Launch or Expansion Restriction in DUB>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Amazon\_Payments/CrossCuttingInitiatives/2025/Infrastructure/DARU/ExpansionException\]\] \(effective 10/30/24\)\\r\\n\\r\\n\[\[Entitlement per Org>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Amazon\_Payments/CrossCuttingInitiatives/2025/Infrastructure/DARU/Entitlement\]\] \(\\"Work in Progress\\". [5]: \"/bin/view/Payments_Services/DARU-2025/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\""},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/BuyerRiskPrevention/CrossCutting/RegionFlexibility/","displayTitle":"Region Flexibility","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1741202512000,"score":0,"rank":2,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n  \\n                    \\n      # Wiki source code of [Region Flexibility][1]
\\n    \\n        \\n              **Primary Owner **[ brp-org-all \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n          \\n                                                                      \\n        Last modified 5 months ago by [psperez][3].\\n      \\n      \\n  \\n---
\\n  \\n    \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n  [Show line numbers][4]\\n  {{transclude name=\\"space:BuyerRiskPrevention.BRPTemplate\\"/}}\\n\\n= Region Flexibility =\\n\\n== Executive Summary ==\\n\\nAmazon's Region Flexibility \(RF\) and Diversify AWS Region Usage \(DARU\) Cross Cutting Initiative \(CCI\) is an Amazon wide and Campaign Category I strategic program to decentralize operations from mega-region \(DUB, IAD, PDX\). For Buyer Risk Prevention \(BRP\), in 2025 this involves migrating critical systems across Payment Risk, Account Integrity, and Abuse Prevention from DUB to new regions: Zaragoza \(ZAZ\) and Frankfurt \(FRA\) with the goal to fully exit DUB by 2026. The goal is to improve resilience, meet evolving regulatory requirements, and enhance customer experience.\\n\\n== Program Goals and Timelines ==\\n\\n\*\*Goal 1: Be prod ready for sub-experience \(BRP is part of cart/checkout and identity\) traffic migration\*\* by 7/31 \(UK/SP marketplaces to ZAZ\) and 8/15 \(DE marketplace to FRA\).\\n\\n\*\*Goal 2: Achieve a 40% IMR costs Reduction in DUB\*\* by 10/16/2025. The bigger needle movers are the Bring Your Own Account fleets which have CORE owned service holding BRP data, we own those fleets for accounting purposes. We will also ensure that we leaving a manageable effort scope to fully exit DUB on 2026.\\n\\n== Migration Approach and Challenges ==\\n\\nRegion Flexibility team decided to perform the traffic switch in phases to reduce the complexity and risk by selecting sub-experiences \(customer experience on Amazon web page that can be migrated mostly independently\) and specific market places on 2025. BRP is only affected by cart/checkout and identity sub-experiences and we need to be ready for traffic switch by 7/31 \(ZAZ\) and 8/15 \(FRA\) for cart/checkout and 8/15 \(ZAZ\) and 8/31 \(FRA\) for identity. All the other marketplaces will remain in DUB until 2026, therefore this means the involved services will need to support traffic in DUB, ZAZ, and FRA during that period.\\n\\nMany of our services are highly dependent on CORE team to run our fraud evaluations, we are working very closely with them to ensure their systems are ready by 6/15 \(or earlier\) to allow at least 6 weeks of service testing. We have agreed with CORE to replicate all the data in each region when necessary to avoid any fraud detection capabilities regression and only performing cross-region calls otherwise. If the BRP service is not latency sensitive, you can call CORE service or any other dependency not yet available on ZAZ/FRA with a cross region call which will add around 30ms with peaks of 65ms.\\n\\nWe are working on a ML testing strategy to ensure that all the intents are well tested and have parity with current DUB performance before any traffic switch.\\n\\n== Tech Strategy ==\\n\\nWe are working on a tech strategy document which will include BRP specific SOP to guide BRP service migration. We are currently reviewing the document with leadership and we will share it here when done. ETA 3/15.\\n\\n== Mitigation Strategies ==\\n\\n\*\*Risk 1: Resource and Sequencing Challenges\*\* BRP's Region Flexibility efforts can encounter risk due to overlapping priorities, competing initiatives, and peak workloads.\\n\\n\*\*Risk 2: Data, Latency, and Model Performance Risks\*\* Decentralizing data and ML models across regions poses risks to fraud detection accuracy, latency, and data availability.\\n\\n\*\*Risk 3: External to BRP Dependency Risks\*\* BRP's success depends on robust mechanisms to monitor dependencies, escalate risks, and maintain alignment with teams like CARML and URES.\\n\\n== Key Points of Contact ==\\n\\n\(% style=\\"width:942px\\" %\)\\n|=\(% style=\\"width: 163px;\\" %\)Role Area|=\(% style=\\"width: 157px;\\" %\)Overall BRP|=\(% style=\\"width: 130px;\\" %\)Payment Risk|=\(% style=\\"width: 178px;\\" %\)Account Integrity|=\(% style=\\"width: 127px;\\" %\)Buyer Abuse|=\(% style=\\"width: 127px;\\" %\)ML|=\(% style=\\"width: 119px;\\" %\)CORE\\n|\(% style=\\"width:163px\\" %\)\*\*STL\*\*|\(% style=\\"width:157px\\" %\)psperez@|\(% style=\\"width:130px\\" %\)psperez@|\(% style=\\"width:178px\\" %\)shisrame@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)psperez@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)planfeng@|\(% style=\\"width:119px\\" %\)prdeepn@\\n|\(% style=\\"width:163px\\" %\)\*\*Tech\*\*|\(% style=\\"width:157px\\" %\)gabeprz@|\(% style=\\"width:130px\\" %\)ritikaj@|\(% style=\\"width:178px\\" %\)bradcamp@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)torbettp@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)chienluc@|\(% style=\\"width:119px\\" %\)prdeepn@\\n|\(% style=\\"width:163px\\" %\)\*\*Senior Leadership\*\*|\(% style=\\"width:157px\\" %\)ujjwalm@|\(% style=\\"width:130px\\" %\)rajks@|\(% style=\\"width:178px\\" %\)ajat@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)mrbohl@|\(% style=\\"width:127px\\" %\)xiaohus@|\(% style=\\"width:119px\\" %\)gddesai@\\n\\n== Office Hours ==\\n\\nWe have weekly BRP Region Flexibility office hours with our Sr SDEs and ML PoCs. Sign up below and we will add you to the call. Please, attend at the time of the slot selected \(10:00 am or 10:15 am\). If you think the topic will take more than 15 minutes, sign up for both slots, please be intentional when taking both slots as there is limited time for the whole BRP org.\\n\\n\*\*How to sign up\*\*\\nAdd your Team/aliases under Team/Owner, the topic/question you would like to discuss under Topic, what kind of support you are seeking including your preference for Abuse/AIT/PRE Sr SDE \(depending on your org ask\) and/or ML by the day before \(Wed\) at 2:00pm. We will forward the meeting to the aliases on Team/Owner by Wed.\\n\\n|=\(% style=\\"width: 87px;\\" %\)Day|\(% style=\\"width:114px\\" %\)Time|=\(% style=\\"width: 139px;\\" %\)Team/Owner|=\(% style=\\"width: 312px;\\" %\)Topic|=\(% style=\\"width: 324px;\\" %\)Support Needed|=\(% style=\\"width: 149px;\\" %\)Useful Links\\n|\(% style=\\"width:87px\\" %\)3/13/25|\(% style=\\"width:114px\\" [4]: \"/bin/view/BuyerRiskPrevention/CrossCutting/RegionFlexibility/?viewer=code&showlinenumbers=1\""},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Users/hhpatel/DARU-2025/","displayTitle":"Payments Services Exit DUB Technical Strategy","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1731357466000,"score":0,"rank":3,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [Payments Services Exit DUB Technical Strategy][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Contact **[hhpatel \(user\)][2]_[ How do I change this value?][3]_\\n \\n \\n Last modified 9 months ago by [hhpatel][4].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][5]\\n == Summary ==\\n\\nAmazon’s SDO \(Stores, Devices, and Other\) Organization is running programs like \[\[Regional Flexibility>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility\]\], and \[\[Diversify AWS Region Usage \(DARU\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/CapacityManagementPlanning/Programs/SDODiversifyAWSRegionUsage/\]\] to enable SDO’s business to operate outside of our existing Retail “mega-regions” of IAD, DUB and PDX. It will enable the movement of traffic across AWS regions for the purposes of cost-efficiency, availability, change in legal compliance requirements, etc. SDO has committed to moving 100% of capacity usage out of DUB \(eu-west-1\) by the end of 2026 in order to support AWS strategic goals outlined in the DARU program.\\n\\\\\\\\Amazon Payments provides the services and integrations points for payment experiences across SDO, AWS, and subsidiaries. These experiences include calls where transactional data correctness and latency are required to support our clients customer experience.\\nThis document provides strategies that are specific to the challenges AP faces when migrating regions or operating concurrently across regions, and referencing centrally provided guidance from RFE.\\n\\n== Program Goal ==\\n\\nBy 10/31/2025, Payments have reduced server usage in DUB by 40% from the baseline established by RFE. There are 2 sub-goals \(1\) For services supporting checkout use-cases, be production ready in ZAZ by 6/30 and FRA by 8/30 \(2\) Services moving from DUB to ZAZ are migrated by 10/30/2025.\\n\\nThis goal is complete when:\\n\*\*Measure 1: \*\*Specific critical calling paths required to support the migrated Checkout marketplaces have minimum TM99 latency regression \(we will work with Checkout to define the acceptable latency regression\).\\n\*\*Measure 2:\*\* Server usage in DUB is reduced by 40% as measured against forecast footprint published by RFE.\\n\\n== Tenets ==\\n\\n\* \*\*Embrace Architectural Flexibility:\*\* We design our systems to easily adapt and scale across new regions, eliminating rigid patterns or concepts that hinder agile expansion.\\n\* \*\*Minimize Client Disruption:\*\* We strive to avoid requiring clients to update beyond merging from the live environment, ensuring seamless transitions. We will not be changing of the payments transactional data consistency model as a primary mechanism of achieving the migration and mitigating latency.\\n\* \*\*Optimize for Low Latency:\*\* We prioritize delivering exceptional customer experiences by architecting our solutions to minimize latency. We accept that some latency increase will occur, but customer perceived latency is our primary metric in measuring the impact. Our regional expansion strategy eliminates cross-region calls, ensuring seamless and responsive interactions for customers in rapidly evolving marketplaces.\\n\* \*\*Leverage Central Tools, Contribute Back:\*\* We maximize the use of automated tooling provided centrally \(by RFE\), while proactively contributing to the development and enhancement of these shared solutions.\\n\* \*\*Streamline Migrations:\*\* We continuously seek opportunities to reduce migration overhead through automation, tooling, and decommissioning, ensuring efficient and lean processes.\\n\* \*\*Migration takes priority over refactoring, tech debt or building new features\*\*: DARU migration is a focussed effort and it should not be delayed due to optimizations in execution around technical debt removal, deprecations or building new features. We encourage teams to consider incremental improvements to architecture that does not add new risks which can significantly impact the effort and timelines.\\n\* \*\*Speed, risk, and latency over cost optimization:\*\* We prioritize speed of execution, risk reduction, latency reduction over the short term increase in IMR. We will have an opportunity to reduce and optimize in the following years of this program.\\n\\n== Central Guidance ==\\n\\nThere is extensive \[\[guidance>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility/Tech\_Guidance/Per-Service\_Region\_Migration\_Guide/\]\] available from Region Flexibility Engineering \(RFE\) to help SDEs in the process of migrating their service across regions.\\n\\\\\\\\Working backwards from the DARU retail website strategy and the dependent sub-experiences - of which Checkout is the primary driver for Payments - we have scoped services into two parts; \(1\) those that are dependen"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Payments_Services/DARU-2025/TechStrategy/","displayTitle":"Payments Services Exit DUB Technical Strategy","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1732632061000,"score":0,"rank":4,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n \\n \\n # Wiki source code of [Payments Services Exit DUB Technical Strategy][1] \\n \\n \\n **Primary Contact **[hhpatel \(user\)][2]_[ How do I change this value?][3]_\\n \\n \\n Last modified 8 months ago by [hhpatel][4].\\n \\n \\n \\n--- \\n \\n \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n [Show line numbers][5]\\n == Summary ==\\n\\nAmazon’s SDO \(Stores, Devices, and Other\) Organization is running programs like \[\[Regional Flexibility>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region\_Flexibility\]\], and \[\[Diversify AWS Region Usage \(DARU\)>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/CapacityManagementPlanning/Programs/SDODiversifyAWSRegionUsage/\]\] to enable SDO’s business to operate outside of our existing Retail “mega-regions” of IAD, DUB and PDX.
