{"content":{"results":[{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/FinanceTechnology/SSE/FINTECH-DARU/","displayTitle":"Diversify AWS Region Usage for Fintech","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1743096431000,"score":0,"rank":1,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n  \\n                    \\n      # Wiki source code of [Diversify AWS Region Usage for Fintech][1]
\\n    \\n        \\n              **Primary Owner **[ fintech-sse-admins \(POSIX\) ][2]\\n          \\n                                                                      \\n        Last modified 4 months ago by [miragen][3].\\n      \\n      \\n  \\n---
\\n  \\n    \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n  [Hide line numbers][4]\\n                            \\n 1: == DARU ==\\n 2: \\n 3: \\n 4: DARU \(Diversify AWS Region Usage\) is a strategic program aimed at addressing long-term availability risks to data center capacity in Amazon's mega-regions. The program focuses on migrating workloads from three AWS mega-regions: IAD \(Americas\), DUB \(Europe & India\), and PDX \(eastern Asia & Australia\).\\n 5: The scope of this program encompasses all AWS services within SDO fleets, including MAWS VPC EC2, Public EC2, Hailstone, Legacy, EBS, S3, Redshift, RDS, DynamoDB, Elasticsearch Service, Lambda, CloudFront, and others deployed in mega regions.\\n 6: The execution strategy involves: 1\) Capacity Type Upgrades - Cascade Lake to Graviton 3, Graviton 2 to Graviton 3, and Mature Gen to Current Gen. 2\) Service Migrations from DUB to ZAZ. 3\) Software Efficiency improvements from JDK 17 Upgrade and Verified Profiler.\\n 7: The program's primary objective is to reduce server utilization in DUB by up to 37% by the end of 2024 through hardware efficiency improvements and migration to alternative regions.\\n 8: AWS has identified specific alternative regions for migration, with ZAZ \(Spain\) and FRA being designated as optimal migration destinations from DUB.\\n 9: These alternative regions offer advantages such as suitable supply runway, secure power outlook, and enhanced customer support capabilities.\\n10: The program is being driven by CloudTune in partnership with Region Flexibility Engineering \(RFE\), with RFE focusing on building foundational solutions, facilitating regional migrations, and making SDO's architecture more flexible for customers and developers.\\n11: The initiative is also an S-Team goal that aims to enable the movement of traffic across AWS regions for purposes of cost-efficiency, availability, and compliance with changing legal requirements.\\n12: For teams participating in the DARU program, there are rate discounts of 30-35% available in new regions like ZAZ compared to existing mega-regions.\\n13: The migration timeline extends to 2029, with the first priority being migration off DUB by Q2'2026.\\n14: \\\\\\\\\*\*SDO Migration Asks from AWS POR \(as of 2/7/24\)\*\*\\n15: \[\[image:1740376273170-849.png||height=\\"328\\" width=\\"1618\\"\]\]\\n16: \\n17: === \*\*2024 S-Team Goal \(\[\[\(% class=\\"wikiinternallink wikiinternallink\\" %\)\*\*733388\*\*>>url:https://kingpin.amazon.com/#/items/733388\]\]\(%%\)\)\*\* ===\\n18: \\n19: \*\*Goal: \*\*Achieve a supportable SDO's Q4’24 peak footprint of 131K servers in Dublin \(eu-west-1/Ireland\)\\n20: \*\*Addition Details? \*\*SDO hosts its technology services via AWS in a handful AWS “mega” regions: Ireland \(eu-west-1/DUB\), Virginia \(us-east-1/IAD\), and Oregon \(us-west-2/PDX\). Today, we are faced with a long-term availability risk to the data center capacity SDO leverages for these services due to concentration in these regions. Concentration in mega regions began to impact SDO’s ability to increase capacity-demand in 2023 and is projected to continue through 2030. Amazon's business will be constrained if SDO does not reduce and eventually exit mega regions by migrating services out between 2024 and 2029. This challenge is motivated by constraints that have been previously shared with leadership. The execution strategy involves: 1\) Capacity Type Upgrades - Cascade Lake to Graviton 3, Graviton 2 to Graviton 3, and Mature Gen to Current Gen. 2\) Service Migrations from DUB to ZAZ. 3\) Software Efficiency improvements from JDK 17 Upgrade and Verified Profiler.\\n21: \*\*Why is this important?\*\* For SDO, the impact of not addressing this challenge results in customer-facing impact that we consider unacceptable: Turning off stores, eliminating peak deal events that excite our customers and grow small-and-medium businesses, hindering emergent scaling due to unanticipated customer behavior, and impeding our ability to meet regulatory Personal Data Protection \(PDP\) policies. Lastly, SDO needs to exit out of DUB by EOY 2026.\\n22: \*\*Success Criteria: \*\*Measurement is based on Q4'24 forecast trajectory. If it's less than or equal to 131K servers, it's GREEN. YELLOW status occurs if the difference between the Q4'24 forecast trajectory and 'committed' reductions is also less than or equal to 131K servers. Exceeding 131K servers makes the goal RED. By EOY 2024, DARU/RF will secure commitments to move 100K servers out of DUB in 2025.\\n23:  \\n24: \\n25: == DARU Program in Fintech ==\\n26: \\n27: For Amazon Payments \(AP\), the DARU program aims to reduce footprint by 31 servers through DUB to ZAZ migration and achieve efficiency of 56 servers through Graviton migration, descaling and deprecation in 2024.\\n28: \[\[https:~~/~~/w.amazon.com/bin/view/Amazon\_Payments/CrossCuttingInitiatives/Infrastructure/DARU>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Amazon\_Payments/CrossCuttingInitiatives/Infrastructure/DARU\]\]\\n29: AP Program Tracker: \[\[https:~~/~~/quip-amazon.com/VwNFAu2aSC0G#temp:C:MYP93049a2de98c4b1ab8ccce1c1>>url:https://quip-amazon.com/VwNFAu2aSC0G#temp:C:MYP93049a2de98c4b1ab8ccce1c1\]\]\\n30: Using a forward-looking multiplier of 1.68, this translates to 62 server migrations to ZAZ and 94 server reductions through efficiencies, targeting a total reduction of 158 servers by January 2025.\\n31: The program is tracked through multiple communication channels:\\n32: \\n33: \* A dedicated Slack channel \(#daru-goal-ap-primary-poc-group-2024\)\\n34: \* Email group: \[\[daru-ap-pocs@amazon.com>>path:mailto:daru-ap-pocs@amazon.com\]\]\\n35: \* Regular office hours sessions\\n36: \\n37: The core group contacts for the program include Ben Mountjoy as Track Sponsor and Swetank Sisodia as Initiative Driver. Teams can subscribe to the AP DARU Program Interest mailing list for regular program updates. Additionally, teams participating in DUB to ZAZ migrations can receive IMR Relief through a one-time DARU credit to offset parallel holding costs incurred during the planned migration window.\\n38: \\\\\\\\From Olga’s email:\\n39: As of Jan 27 2025, FinTech did not receive an assigned quota. Per meeting with newly appointed DARU SPOC, they asked FinTech to target to have <360 server equivalents \(EC2 + non-EC-2\) in DUB as of October 2025. This is 40% less than in October 2024 tracker \(600 server equivalents\) noted in their tracker.\\n40: \\n41: Fintech DARU Dashboard:\\n42: \\n43: https:~/~/us-east-1.quicksight.aws.amazon.com/sn/dashboards/920605f0-b871-449a-bcdd-914c6155e83e?#\\n44: \\n45: \[\[https:~~/~~/w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune\_Analytics/Dashboard/DARU\_Goal\_Measurement\_Dashboard/>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune\_Analytics/Dashboard/DARU\_Goal\_Measurement\_Dashboard/\]\]\\n46: \\n47: = Meet the exit DUB FinTech Support Team =\\n48: \\n49: \\n50: {{transclude name=\\"HyperBadgeJob\\" args=\\"username=miragen|firstname=Mirage|job= FinTech Program Manager |jobfontsize=7|color=Blue|size=1.5\\"/}}\\n51: \\n52: {{transclude name=\\"HyperBadgeJob\\" args=\\"username=govpat|firstname=Govind|job=Sr. Systems Engineer|jobfontsize=7|color=Blue|size=1.5\\"/}}\\n53: \\n54: \(% style=\\"text-align: center;\\" %\)\\n55: = Office Hours =\\n56: \\n57: == How can you reach us? ==\\n58: \\n59: \* Office Hours\*\* \*\*will be held\*\* virtually every Thursday from 1:00 pm PST to 01:30 pm PST\*\*.\\n60: \* You can contact us by signing-up office hours at least 48 hours prior to the office hours window.\\n61: \* All office hours slots must have a \*\*\[\[SIM>>https://issues.amazon.com/issues/create?assignedFolder=2143c778-2a75-44a1-9860-a78443e699d5\]\]\*\*. \\n62: \* Create a \*\*\[\[SIM>>https://issues.amazon.com/issues/create?assignedFolder=2143c778-2a75-44a1-9860-a78443e699d5\]\]\*\* by inquiry for: DARU/ExIT DUB, C\(% data-dobid=\\"hdw\\" %\)ompliance\(%%\) etc.\\n63: \* Office hours are broken into \*\*15 minutes time slots\*\*, so please come prepared so we can cover your topic within this time.\\n64: \* \(% style=\\"color:red\\" %\)\*\*DO NOT\*\*\(%%\) double-book a slot that's already taken.\\n65: \* \(% style=\\"background-color:#f1c40f\\" %\)\*\*Chime Meeting ID: \*\*\(%%\) \(% style=\\"font-family:~\\"Calibri~\\",sans-serif; font-size:11.0pt; mso-ansi-language:EN-US; mso-bidi-language:AR-SA; mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri; mso-fareast-language:EN-US; mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin\\" %\)5086622516\(%%\) | United States Toll-Free \(1\): +1 855-552-4463 Meeting ID: 5086622516\\n66: \* For urgent needs please contact us at \*\*Chime\*\*\\n67: \* If your query is resolved and/or you cannot make it to your booked slot, please cancel your reservation.\\n68: \\n69: \(% style=\\"text-align: center;\\" %\)\\n70: = Sign Up Here =\\n71: \\n72: {{enableSortableTables/}}\\n73: \\n74: \(% class=\\"doOddEven filterable grid sortable\\" id=\\"tableid\\" style=\\"width:1293px\\" %\)\\n75: \(% class=\\"sortHeader\\" %\)|=\(% style=\\"width: 60px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)#|=\(% style=\\"width: 100px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Date|=\(% style=\\"width: 140px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Time |=\(% style=\\"width: 135px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Requester|=\(% style=\\"width: 180px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Team ~| Application|=\(% style=\\"width: 259px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)SIM Link \(If any\)|=\(% style=\\"width: 399px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Summary \\n76: |\(% style=\\"text-align:center; width:180px\\" %\) |\(% style=\\"width:259px\\" %\) |\(% style=\\"width:399px\\" %\) \\n87: |\(% style=\\"text-align:center; width:60px\\" %\) |\(% style=\\"text-align:center; width:100px\\" %\) |\(% style=\\"text-align:center; OpsTech Solutions Services","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1752858871000,"score":0,"rank":9,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n  \\n                    \\n      # Wiki source code of [Diverisfy AWS Region Usage - OpsTech Solutions Services][1]
\\n    \\n        \\n              **Primary Owner **[ otie \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n          \\n                                                                      \\n        Last modified 28 days ago by [sudnaidu][3].\\n      \\n      \\n  \\n---
\\n  \\n    \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n  [Hide line numbers][4]\\n                            \\n 1: Amazon is mandating the migration of all SDO AWS capacity out of the DUB region by the end of 2026, with a target of moving out 40% of 2024 peak footprint \(EC2 and non-EC2\) by October 16, 2025. The \\"Exit DUB\\" initiative was approved as a Category I \(must plan in OP1\), \[\[cross-cutting initiative in Stores for 2025>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/ECommerceFoundation/Cross\_Cutting\_Projects/2025Planning/2025\_Initiatives/\]\] in support of the \[\[S-Team goal>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/CapacityManagementPlanning/Programs/SDODiversifyAWSRegionUsage/Planning/2025GoalGuidance\]\] \(\[\[Kingpin>>url:https://kingpin.amazon.com/#/items/907533\]\]\). SDO businesses face long-term compute risk due to capacity concentration in 3 AWS mega regions - DUB, IAD, PDX. Proposed target regions for DUB workloads \(EU/MENA/IN Operations\) to migrate include ZAZ \(Spain\), FRA \(Germany\), and HYD \(India\). Strategically, migrating to non-concentrated AWS regions results in benefits such as: \(1\) Reduced cost-to-serve - IMR for foundational services in destination regions is ~~30-35% cheaper compared to DUB; \(2\) Improving latency for end-users by moving workloads closer to where customers are located; \(3\) Minimized impact of capacity constraints; \(4\) Faster response to data-residency compliance legislation.\\n 2: \\n 3: \\n 4: \\n 5: \\n 6: OTS \(OpsTech Solutions\) scope in DARU \(Diversify AWS Region Usage\) program is divided into two workstreams. Workstream 1 will support FTR \(Fulfillment Technologies and Robotics\) goal to exit DUB by 2026, and workstream 2 will migrate OTS owned services out of DUB.\\n 7: \\n 8: \\n 9: \*\*Workstream 1:\*\* This workstream specifically addresses immediate OTS activities related to the DUB region exit of FTR services in 2025 and excludes migration activities for North American regions \(IAD and PDX, scheduled for exit by 2029\). FTR is establishing infrastructure in the ZAZ \(eu-south-2\) region for latency sensitive Tier 1 services \[FAQ 5\] in Q1 and Q2 2025, enabling testing with a greenfield EU ARS FC launch \(DSA2 - MoC\) in Q3 2025. After addressing any issues identified during the new FC launch, a brownfield FC will be migrated from DUB to ZAZ in Q4 2025. Testing with a greenfield FC instead of operational brownfield FC will reduce the complexity of existing FC data migrations and provide a buffer to fix any issues that may arise. MAD6 \(TNS\) was selected as the brownfield pilot site to be migrated from DUB to ZAZ after a successful DSA2 launch. Since there is no CORP VPC in ZAZ, only externalized applications will be available for use by Operations in ZAZ \(Hot Topics\). After a successful MoC ARS site launch and a SoC TNS site migration in 2025, the strategy for 2026 is to allow as many greenfield sites launch out of ZAZ as possible and migrate piloted brownfield site types to ZAZ region.\\n10: \\n11: \\n12: \*\*Workstream 2:\*\* While this document serves as input for 2026 OP1 planning for OTS services migrating out of DUB, it currently does not encompass the complete scope of OTS infrastructure migration from DUB, such as SDWAN head ends, Outpost homing to DUB or ZAZ, Local zones, or DX connections \(Page-0\). These elements must be addressed by OTS service owners in 2026 OP1 for their services hosted in DUB.\\n13: \\n14: \\n15: \*\*Region Flexibility Engineering Program Tenets\*\*\\n16: \\n17: 1. Supporting capacity assurance for Amazon and AWS customers is higher priority than architectural improvements or making services region flexible. Where these enhancements do not add risk, Amazon intentionally invests in them.\\n18: 1. Experience owners, in partnership with RFE, own the responsibility of business continuity and impact in both duration and magnitude to the customer experiences \(e.g., latency, availability\); RFE will help resolve these decisions and provide visibility at appropriate business levels.\\n19: 1. RFE owns enabling and guiding SDO teams, identifying broadly impacting bottlenecks, regulating the federated impact of owners’ actions, and auditing progress on migrations and region flexibility. SDO teams own migrating their services & data and making those systems region flexible.\\n20: 1. Decoupling the work of individual teams as they set up their services, experiment, and make their data accessible cross-region is a priority for meeting exit DUB timelines.\\n21: 1. RFE prefers to move data and workloads fewer times but recognizes this will not always be feasible \(e.g., first move IN Shopping experiences to ZAZ, then HYD\).\\n22: \\n23: \*\*FAQs:\*\*\\n24: \\n25: \*\*Q1: What is the difference between DARU and Region Flexibility?\*\*\\n26: \\n27: \*\*A:\*\* To address the capacity challenge, \[\[CloudTune>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/Home\]\], in partnership with Region Flexibility Engineering \(RFE\), is driving an SDO-wide program, Diversify AWS Region Usage \(DARU\) in DUB \(Ireland\), IAD \(USA\), and PDX \(USA\) regions. DARU serves as the overarching umbrella program aimed at addressing SDO’s multi-year capacity assurance risks. The DARU program has key dependencies on the RFE program. RFE focuses on building foundational solutions, facilitating regional migrations, enabling/accelerating migrations to address technological challenges, and making SDO's architecture more flexible for customers and developers. The DARU program is designed to implement a multi-year migration strategy that aligns with AWS's requirements.\\n28: \\n29: \\n30: RFE aims to make it easy to serve existing SDO \(Stores, Devices, and Other\) customer traffic from new AWS regions. The Region Flexibility team is responsible for establishing new solutions and architectural patterns to help services owners get into regions more quickly, in partnership with experts at Amazon working in domains like data and configuration. RF owns the vision for how SDO gets into new regions, and influence which regions solutions move into considering regulatory requirements, latency, cost efficiency, and developer experience.\\n31: \\n32: \\n33: \*\*Q2:\*\*  \*\*Why is DARU important?\*\*\\n34: \\n35: \*\*A:\*\* SDO businesses face long-term compute risk due to capacity concentration in 3 AWS mega regions - DUB, IAD, PDX. Proposed target regions for DUB workloads \(EU/MENA/IN Operations\) to migrate include ZAZ \(Spain\), FRA \(Germany\), and HYD \(India\). Strategically, migrating to non-concentrated AWS regions results in benefits such as: \(1\) Reduced cost-to-serve - IMR for foundational services in destination regions is ~~30-35% cheaper compared to DUB; \(2\) Improving latency for end-users by moving workloads closer to where customers are located; \(3\) Minimized impact of capacity constraints; \(4\) Faster response to data-residency compliance legislation.\\n36: \\n37: \\n38: \*\*Q3: What is Cloudtune?\*\*\\n39: \\n40: \*\*A:\*\* \[\[CloudTune>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/Home\]\] is a program focused on scaling CDO fleets to optimal levels while minimizing service owner overhead without adding availability risk. CloudTune is composed of three initiatives:\\n41: \\n42: \* Forecasting - we provide Post OPF Traffic, Physical Order Rate, Digital Order Rate, Service Call Volume and VIP forecasts\\n43: \* Scaling Planner - we partner with AWS Auto Scaling to develop solutions that optimally scale CDO fleets according to demand\\n44: \* Capacity Management - we are the single point of contact regarding capacity planning and shaping demand to available supply for CDO.\\n45: \\n46: \*\*Q4: What is EDAMS?\*\*\\n47: \\n48: \*\*A: \*\*Edge Device Application Management System \(EDAMS\) facilitates client interactions with various peripheral devices such as label printers, WAT machines, and Cubiscans by routing client requests without relying on specific network or IP address configurations. EDAMS provides CDK pipelines to orchestrate the deployment of custom software, on edge compute devices. Additionally, EDAMS offers an Edge Device Console, a web-based user interface for monitoring and managing all edge compute devices. Another key function of EDAMS is the management of the Certificate Manager Infrastructure, which handles the distribution and rotation of end entity certificates for thin clients \(like HP T640\), tablets \(like Pinnacle+\), and handheld scanners \(like MC33, TC57, PM85, PM560\). EDAMS currently relies heavily on AWS IoT and Greengrass V1 for edge device management and communication. However, with Greengrass V1 being deprecated and unavailable in new regions like ZAZ, equivalent functionality needs to be deployed to ensure core services continue to function.\\n49: \\n50: \\n51: \*\*Q5: What is a Tier 1 service for DUB to ZAZ migrations?\*\*\\n52: \\n53: \*\*A: \*\*The setup of the new fulfillment software \(AFT, MSP, AR\) in the ZAZ region is categorized into distinct groups based on their interdependencies, functionality, and migration requirements. The \*\*first group\*\* consists of 240 \[\[Tier1>>url:https://quip-amazon.com/DMRlAyQAEhF8/DARU-DSA2-Tier1-Pipelines#temp:C:aNc0a7a5f7b84c4474ab75280adb\]\] services, which are tightly coupled, latency sensitive, interdependent \(Pick, Pack, Sort, etc.\) and software stack \(not data\) will be replicated together as a single unit to ensure seamless operation and prevent any disruptions or compatibility issues. The \*\*second group\*\* comprises regional services \(Skumaster, labor planning, etc.\), which do not have a specific warehouse identifier associated with them and asynchronous services \(SNS, SQS, etc.\). The regional services will either continue to operate from DUB, and serve clients in both the DUB and ZAZ regions or create a new stack is created in ZAZ, and ensure data consistency between the DUB and ZAZ stacks to maintain seamless service delivery to clients in their respective regions. The asynchronous services \(SNS, SQS, etc.\) services operate in a decoupled manner, allowing flexibility during the migration process. The \*\*third group\*\* includes non-Tier1 services \(reporting tools\), which, like the asynchronous services, can be replicated and set up in isolation without causing disruptions to other services. Further details can be found in \[\[AFT DARU Program Goals>>url:https://amazon.awsapps.com/workdocs-amazon/index.html#/document/3a1b9e83e808327351ec7ed0acaa004a5f0d2cd06ff5f778f035e800dda536af\]\] document.\\n54: \\n55: \*\*Contact Info:\*\*\\n56: DARU-OTS Program Reference Links Wiki: \[\[https:~~/~~/w.amazon.com/bin/view/OTIE/InfrastructurePrograms/DARU-OTS>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/OTIE/InfrastructurePrograms/DARU-OTS\]\]\\n57: \\n58: eMail/interest list: \[\[daru-ots-interest@amazon.com>>url:http://daru-ots-interest@amazon.com\]\]\\n59: \\n60: Slack Channel: \[\[#daru-ots-interest>>url:https://amazon.enterprise.slack.com/archives/C094U0C2Z5K\]\]\\n61: \\n62: Weekly DARU Office hours: Every Monday 1:30 PM to 2:30 PM EST \(\[\[Zoom Call link>>url:https://amazon.zoom.us/j/7867175185?pwd=zvPD4GEZqo7qve9rDQtw5EIyMDatMZ.1&omn=97210998831&from=addon\]\]\)\\n\\n"}

{"content":{"results":[{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/FinanceTechnology/SSE/FINTECH-DARU/","displayTitle":"Diversify AWS Region Usage for Fintech","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1743096431000,"score":0,"rank":1,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n  \\n                    \\n      # Wiki source code of [Diversify AWS Region Usage for Fintech][1]
\\n    \\n        \\n              **Primary Owner **[ fintech-sse-admins \(POSIX\) ][2]\\n          \\n                                                                      \\n        Last modified 4 months ago by [miragen][3].\\n      \\n      \\n  \\n---
\\n  \\n    \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n  [Hide line numbers][4]\\n                            \\n 1: == DARU ==\\n 2: \\n 3: \\n 4: DARU \(Diversify AWS Region Usage\) is a strategic program aimed at addressing long-term availability risks to data center capacity in Amazon's mega-regions. The program focuses on migrating workloads from three AWS mega-regions: IAD \(Americas\), DUB \(Europe & India\), and PDX \(eastern Asia & Australia\).\\n 5: The scope of this program encompasses all AWS services within SDO fleets, including MAWS VPC EC2, Public EC2, Hailstone, Legacy, EBS, S3, Redshift, RDS, DynamoDB, Elasticsearch Service, Lambda, CloudFront, and others deployed in mega regions.\\n 6: The execution strategy involves: 1\) Capacity Type Upgrades - Cascade Lake to Graviton 3, Graviton 2 to Graviton 3, and Mature Gen to Current Gen. 2\) Service Migrations from DUB to ZAZ. 3\) Software Efficiency improvements from JDK 17 Upgrade and Verified Profiler.\\n 7: The program's primary objective is to reduce server utilization in DUB by up to 37% by the end of 2024 through hardware efficiency improvements and migration to alternative regions.\\n 8: AWS has identified specific alternative regions for migration, with ZAZ \(Spain\) and FRA being designated as optimal migration destinations from DUB.\\n 9: These alternative regions offer advantages such as suitable supply runway, secure power outlook, and enhanced customer support capabilities.\\n10: The program is being driven by CloudTune in partnership with Region Flexibility Engineering \(RFE\), with RFE focusing on building foundational solutions, facilitating regional migrations, and making SDO's architecture more flexible for customers and developers.\\n11: The initiative is also an S-Team goal that aims to enable the movement of traffic across AWS regions for purposes of cost-efficiency, availability, and compliance with changing legal requirements.\\n12: For teams participating in the DARU program, there are rate discounts of 30-35% available in new regions like ZAZ compared to existing mega-regions.\\n13: The migration timeline extends to 2029, with the first priority being migration off DUB by Q2'2026.\\n14: \\\\\\\\\*\*SDO Migration Asks from AWS POR \(as of 2/7/24\)\*\*\\n15: \[\[image:1740376273170-849.png||height=\\"328\\" width=\\"1618\\"\]\]\\n16: \\n17: === \*\*2024 S-Team Goal \(\[\[\(% class=\\"wikiinternallink wikiinternallink\\" %\)\*\*733388\*\*>>url:https://kingpin.amazon.com/#/items/733388\]\]\(%%\)\)\*\* ===\\n18: \\n19: \*\*Goal: \*\*Achieve a supportable SDO's Q4’24 peak footprint of 131K servers in Dublin \(eu-west-1/Ireland\)\\n20: \*\*Addition Details? \*\*SDO hosts its technology services via AWS in a handful AWS “mega” regions: Ireland \(eu-west-1/DUB\), Virginia \(us-east-1/IAD\), and Oregon \(us-west-2/PDX\). Today, we are faced with a long-term availability risk to the data center capacity SDO leverages for these services due to concentration in these regions. Concentration in mega regions began to impact SDO’s ability to increase capacity-demand in 2023 and is projected to continue through 2030. Amazon's business will be constrained if SDO does not reduce and eventually exit mega regions by migrating services out between 2024 and 2029. This challenge is motivated by constraints that have been previously shared with leadership. The execution strategy involves: 1\) Capacity Type Upgrades - Cascade Lake to Graviton 3, Graviton 2 to Graviton 3, and Mature Gen to Current Gen. 2\) Service Migrations from DUB to ZAZ. 3\) Software Efficiency improvements from JDK 17 Upgrade and Verified Profiler.\\n21: \*\*Why is this important?\*\* For SDO, the impact of not addressing this challenge results in customer-facing impact that we consider unacceptable: Turning off stores, eliminating peak deal events that excite our customers and grow small-and-medium businesses, hindering emergent scaling due to unanticipated customer behavior, and impeding our ability to meet regulatory Personal Data Protection \(PDP\) policies. Lastly, SDO needs to exit out of DUB by EOY 2026.\\n22: \*\*Success Criteria: \*\*Measurement is based on Q4'24 forecast trajectory. If it's less than or equal to 131K servers, it's GREEN. YELLOW status occurs if the difference between the Q4'24 forecast trajectory and 'committed' reductions is also less than or equal to 131K servers. Exceeding 131K servers makes the goal RED. By EOY 2024, DARU/RF will secure commitments to move 100K servers out of DUB in 2025.\\n23:  \\n24: \\n25: == DARU Program in Fintech ==\\n26: \\n27: For Amazon Payments \(AP\), the DARU program aims to reduce footprint by 31 servers through DUB to ZAZ migration and achieve efficiency of 56 servers through Graviton migration, descaling and deprecation in 2024.\\n28: \[\[https:~~/~~/w.amazon.com/bin/view/Amazon\_Payments/CrossCuttingInitiatives/Infrastructure/DARU>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Amazon\_Payments/CrossCuttingInitiatives/Infrastructure/DARU\]\]\\n29: AP Program Tracker: \[\[https:~~/~~/quip-amazon.com/VwNFAu2aSC0G#temp:C:MYP93049a2de98c4b1ab8ccce1c1>>url:https://quip-amazon.com/VwNFAu2aSC0G#temp:C:MYP93049a2de98c4b1ab8ccce1c1\]\]\\n30: Using a forward-looking multiplier of 1.68, this translates to 62 server migrations to ZAZ and 94 server reductions through efficiencies, targeting a total reduction of 158 servers by January 2025.\\n31: The program is tracked through multiple communication channels:\\n32: \\n33: \* A dedicated Slack channel \(#daru-goal-ap-primary-poc-group-2024\)\\n34: \* Email group: \[\[daru-ap-pocs@amazon.com>>path:mailto:daru-ap-pocs@amazon.com\]\]\\n35: \* Regular office hours sessions\\n36: \\n37: The core group contacts for the program include Ben Mountjoy as Track Sponsor and Swetank Sisodia as Initiative Driver. Teams can subscribe to the AP DARU Program Interest mailing list for regular program updates. Additionally, teams participating in DUB to ZAZ migrations can receive IMR Relief through a one-time DARU credit to offset parallel holding costs incurred during the planned migration window.\\n38: \\\\\\\\From Olga’s email:\\n39: As of Jan 27 2025, FinTech did not receive an assigned quota. Per meeting with newly appointed DARU SPOC, they asked FinTech to target to have <360 server equivalents \(EC2 + non-EC-2\) in DUB as of October 2025. This is 40% less than in October 2024 tracker \(600 server equivalents\) noted in their tracker.\\n40: \\n41: Fintech DARU Dashboard:\\n42: \\n43: https:~/~/us-east-1.quicksight.aws.amazon.com/sn/dashboards/920605f0-b871-449a-bcdd-914c6155e83e?#\\n44: \\n45: \[\[https:~~/~~/w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune\_Analytics/Dashboard/DARU\_Goal\_Measurement\_Dashboard/>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune\_Analytics/Dashboard/DARU\_Goal\_Measurement\_Dashboard/\]\]\\n46: \\n47: = Meet the exit DUB FinTech Support Team =\\n48: \\n49: \\n50: {{transclude name=\\"HyperBadgeJob\\" args=\\"username=miragen|firstname=Mirage|job= FinTech Program Manager |jobfontsize=7|color=Blue|size=1.5\\"/}}\\n51: \\n52: {{transclude name=\\"HyperBadgeJob\\" args=\\"username=govpat|firstname=Govind|job=Sr. Systems Engineer|jobfontsize=7|color=Blue|size=1.5\\"/}}\\n53: \\n54: \(% style=\\"text-align: center;\\" %\)\\n55: = Office Hours =\\n56: \\n57: == How can you reach us? ==\\n58: \\n59: \* Office Hours\*\* \*\*will be held\*\* virtually every Thursday from 1:00 pm PST to 01:30 pm PST\*\*.\\n60: \* You can contact us by signing-up office hours at least 48 hours prior to the office hours window.\\n61: \* All office hours slots must have a \*\*\[\[SIM>>https://issues.amazon.com/issues/create?assignedFolder=2143c778-2a75-44a1-9860-a78443e699d5\]\]\*\*. \\n62: \* Create a \*\*\[\[SIM>>https://issues.amazon.com/issues/create?assignedFolder=2143c778-2a75-44a1-9860-a78443e699d5\]\]\*\* by inquiry for: DARU/ExIT DUB, C\(% data-dobid=\\"hdw\\" %\)ompliance\(%%\) etc.\\n63: \* Office hours are broken into \*\*15 minutes time slots\*\*, so please come prepared so we can cover your topic within this time.\\n64: \* \(% style=\\"color:red\\" %\)\*\*DO NOT\*\*\(%%\) double-book a slot that's already taken.\\n65: \* \(% style=\\"background-color:#f1c40f\\" %\)\*\*Chime Meeting ID: \*\*\(%%\) \(% style=\\"font-family:~\\"Calibri~\\",sans-serif; font-size:11.0pt; mso-ansi-language:EN-US; mso-bidi-language:AR-SA; mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri; mso-fareast-language:EN-US; mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin\\" %\)5086622516\(%%\) | United States Toll-Free \(1\): +1 855-552-4463 Meeting ID: 5086622516\\n66: \* For urgent needs please contact us at \*\*Chime\*\*\\n67: \* If your query is resolved and/or you cannot make it to your booked slot, please cancel your reservation.\\n68: \\n69: \(% style=\\"text-align: center;\\" %\)\\n70: = Sign Up Here =\\n71: \\n72: {{enableSortableTables/}}\\n73: \\n74: \(% class=\\"doOddEven filterable grid sortable\\" id=\\"tableid\\" style=\\"width:1293px\\" %\)\\n75: \(% class=\\"sortHeader\\" %\)|=\(% style=\\"width: 60px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)#|=\(% style=\\"width: 100px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Date|=\(% style=\\"width: 140px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Time |=\(% style=\\"width: 135px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Requester|=\(% style=\\"width: 180px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Team ~| Application|=\(% style=\\"width: 259px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)SIM Link \(If any\)|=\(% style=\\"width: 399px;\\" %\)\(% style=\\"font-size:14px\\" %\)Summary \\n76: |\(% style=\\"text-align:center; Diversify AWS Region Usage","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1707422013000,"score":0,"rank":4,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"error","error":"Too many redirects"}"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/SPS-RegionFlex/","displayTitle":"Region Flex for Selling Partner Services (SPS)","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1733856077000,"score":0,"rank":5,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"error","error":"Too many redirects"}"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/FxPlatform/Dev/Projects/Daru/RegionFlexExit-DUBplanforACC/","displayTitle":"Region Flex (Exit-DUB) plan for ACC","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1737010004000,"score":0,"rank":6,"categoryList":["Quip2Wiki","Quip2Wiki:xhtml"],"body":"{"status":"error","error":"Too many redirects"}"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Users/shwthy/Quip/RegionFlexExit-DUBplanforACC/","displayTitle":"Region Flex (Exit-DUB) plan for ACC","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1737009429000,"score":0,"rank":7,"categoryList":["Quip2Wiki","Quip2Wiki:xhtml"],"body":"{"status":"error","error":"Too many redirects"}"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/SNOWHome/DARU/RegionProperty/","displayTitle":"AWS Region-Based FC Mapping for Region Flexibility Program","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1744228214000,"score":0,"rank":8,"categoryList":["Quip2Wiki","Quip2Wiki:xhtml"],"body":"{"status":"error","error":"Too many redirects"}"},{"url":"https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/OTIE/InfrastructurePrograms/DARU-OTS/","displayTitle":"Diverisfy AWS Region Usage - OpsTech Solutions Services","domain":"wiki","resultType":"DOCUMENT","modificationDate":1752858871000,"score":0,"rank":9,"categoryList":[],"body":"{"status":"success","content":"\\n  \\n                    \\n      # Wiki source code of [Diverisfy AWS Region Usage - OpsTech Solutions Services][1]
\\n    \\n        \\n              **Primary Owner **[ otie \(LDAP\) ][2]\\n          \\n                                                                      \\n        Last modified 28 days ago by [sudnaidu][3].\\n      \\n      \\n  \\n---
\\n  \\n    \\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n  [Hide line numbers][4]\\n                            \\n 1: Amazon is mandating the migration of all SDO AWS capacity out of the DUB region by the end of 2026, with a target of moving out 40% of 2024 peak footprint \(EC2 and non-EC2\) by October 16, 2025. The \\"Exit DUB\\" initiative was approved as a Category I \(must plan in OP1\), \[\[cross-cutting initiative in Stores for 2025>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/ECommerceFoundation/Cross\_Cutting\_Projects/2025Planning/2025\_Initiatives/\]\] in support of the \[\[S-Team goal>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/CapacityManagementPlanning/Programs/SDODiversifyAWSRegionUsage/Planning/2025GoalGuidance\]\] \(\[\[Kingpin>>url:https://kingpin.amazon.com/#/items/907533\]\]\). SDO businesses face long-term compute risk due to capacity concentration in 3 AWS mega regions - DUB, IAD, PDX. Proposed target regions for DUB workloads \(EU/MENA/IN Operations\) to migrate include ZAZ \(Spain\), FRA \(Germany\), and HYD \(India\). Strategically, migrating to non-concentrated AWS regions results in benefits such as: \(1\) Reduced cost-to-serve - IMR for foundational services in destination regions is ~~30-35% cheaper compared to DUB; \(2\) Improving latency for end-users by moving workloads closer to where customers are located; \(3\) Minimized impact of capacity constraints; \(4\) Faster response to data-residency compliance legislation.\\n 2: \\n 3: \\n 4: \\n 5: \\n 6: OTS \(OpsTech Solutions\) scope in DARU \(Diversify AWS Region Usage\) program is divided into two workstreams. Workstream 1 will support FTR \(Fulfillment Technologies and Robotics\) goal to exit DUB by 2026, and workstream 2 will migrate OTS owned services out of DUB.\\n 7: \\n 8: \\n 9: \*\*Workstream 1:\*\* This workstream specifically addresses immediate OTS activities related to the DUB region exit of FTR services in 2025 and excludes migration activities for North American regions \(IAD and PDX, scheduled for exit by 2029\). FTR is establishing infrastructure in the ZAZ \(eu-south-2\) region for latency sensitive Tier 1 services \[FAQ 5\] in Q1 and Q2 2025, enabling testing with a greenfield EU ARS FC launch \(DSA2 - MoC\) in Q3 2025. After addressing any issues identified during the new FC launch, a brownfield FC will be migrated from DUB to ZAZ in Q4 2025. Testing with a greenfield FC instead of operational brownfield FC will reduce the complexity of existing FC data migrations and provide a buffer to fix any issues that may arise. MAD6 \(TNS\) was selected as the brownfield pilot site to be migrated from DUB to ZAZ after a successful DSA2 launch. Since there is no CORP VPC in ZAZ, only externalized applications will be available for use by Operations in ZAZ \(Hot Topics\). After a successful MoC ARS site launch and a SoC TNS site migration in 2025, the strategy for 2026 is to allow as many greenfield sites launch out of ZAZ as possible and migrate piloted brownfield site types to ZAZ region.\\n10: \\n11: \\n12: \*\*Workstream 2:\*\* While this document serves as input for 2026 OP1 planning for OTS services migrating out of DUB, it currently does not encompass the complete scope of OTS infrastructure migration from DUB, such as SDWAN head ends, Outpost homing to DUB or ZAZ, Local zones, or DX connections \(Page-0\). These elements must be addressed by OTS service owners in 2026 OP1 for their services hosted in DUB.\\n13: \\n14: \\n15: \*\*Region Flexibility Engineering Program Tenets\*\*\\n16: \\n17: 1. Supporting capacity assurance for Amazon and AWS customers is higher priority than architectural improvements or making services region flexible. Where these enhancements do not add risk, Amazon intentionally invests in them.\\n18: 1. Experience owners, in partnership with RFE, own the responsibility of business continuity and impact in both duration and magnitude to the customer experiences \(e.g., latency, availability\); RFE will help resolve these decisions and provide visibility at appropriate business levels.\\n19: 1. RFE owns enabling and guiding SDO teams, identifying broadly impacting bottlenecks, regulating the federated impact of owners’ actions, and auditing progress on migrations and region flexibility. SDO teams own migrating their services & data and making those systems region flexible.\\n20: 1. Decoupling the work of individual teams as they set up their services, experiment, and make their data accessible cross-region is a priority for meeting exit DUB timelines.\\n21: 1. RFE prefers to move data and workloads fewer times but recognizes this will not always be feasible \(e.g., first move IN Shopping experiences to ZAZ, then HYD\).\\n22: \\n23: \*\*FAQs:\*\*\\n24: \\n25: \*\*Q1: What is the difference between DARU and Region Flexibility?\*\*\\n26: \\n27: \*\*A:\*\* To address the capacity challenge, \[\[CloudTune>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/Home\]\], in partnership with Region Flexibility Engineering \(RFE\), is driving an SDO-wide program, Diversify AWS Region Usage \(DARU\) in DUB \(Ireland\), IAD \(USA\), and PDX \(USA\) regions. DARU serves as the overarching umbrella program aimed at addressing SDO’s multi-year capacity assurance risks. The DARU program has key dependencies on the RFE program. RFE focuses on building foundational solutions, facilitating regional migrations, enabling/accelerating migrations to address technological challenges, and making SDO's architecture more flexible for customers and developers. The DARU program is designed to implement a multi-year migration strategy that aligns with AWS's requirements.\\n28: \\n29: \\n30: RFE aims to make it easy to serve existing SDO \(Stores, Devices, and Other\) customer traffic from new AWS regions. The Region Flexibility team is responsible for establishing new solutions and architectural patterns to help services owners get into regions more quickly, in partnership with experts at Amazon working in domains like data and configuration. RF owns the vision for how SDO gets into new regions, and influence which regions solutions move into considering regulatory requirements, latency, cost efficiency, and developer experience.\\n31: \\n32: \\n33: \*\*Q2:\*\*  \*\*Why is DARU important?\*\*\\n34: \\n35: \*\*A:\*\* SDO businesses face long-term compute risk due to capacity concentration in 3 AWS mega regions - DUB, IAD, PDX. Proposed target regions for DUB workloads \(EU/MENA/IN Operations\) to migrate include ZAZ \(Spain\), FRA \(Germany\), and HYD \(India\). Strategically, migrating to non-concentrated AWS regions results in benefits such as: \(1\) Reduced cost-to-serve - IMR for foundational services in destination regions is ~~30-35% cheaper compared to DUB; \(2\) Improving latency for end-users by moving workloads closer to where customers are located; \(3\) Minimized impact of capacity constraints; \(4\) Faster response to data-residency compliance legislation.\\n36: \\n37: \\n38: \*\*Q3: What is Cloudtune?\*\*\\n39: \\n40: \*\*A:\*\* \[\[CloudTune>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/CloudTune/Home\]\] is a program focused on scaling CDO fleets to optimal levels while minimizing service owner overhead without adding availability risk. CloudTune is composed of three initiatives:\\n41: \\n42: \* Forecasting - we provide Post OPF Traffic, Physical Order Rate, Digital Order Rate, Service Call Volume and VIP forecasts\\n43: \* Scaling Planner - we partner with AWS Auto Scaling to develop solutions that optimally scale CDO fleets according to demand\\n44: \* Capacity Management - we are the single point of contact regarding capacity planning and shaping demand to available supply for CDO.\\n45: \\n46: \*\*Q4: What is EDAMS?\*\*\\n47: \\n48: \*\*A: \*\*Edge Device Application Management System \(EDAMS\) facilitates client interactions with various peripheral devices such as label printers, WAT machines, and Cubiscans by routing client requests without relying on specific network or IP address configurations. EDAMS provides CDK pipelines to orchestrate the deployment of custom software, on edge compute devices. Additionally, EDAMS offers an Edge Device Console, a web-based user interface for monitoring and managing all edge compute devices. Another key function of EDAMS is the management of the Certificate Manager Infrastructure, which handles the distribution and rotation of end entity certificates for thin clients \(like HP T640\), tablets \(like Pinnacle+\), and handheld scanners \(like MC33, TC57, PM85, PM560\). EDAMS currently relies heavily on AWS IoT and Greengrass V1 for edge device management and communication. However, with Greengrass V1 being deprecated and unavailable in new regions like ZAZ, equivalent functionality needs to be deployed to ensure core services continue to function.\\n49: \\n50: \\n51: \*\*Q5: What is a Tier 1 service for DUB to ZAZ migrations?\*\*\\n52: \\n53: \*\*A: \*\*The setup of the new fulfillment software \(AFT, MSP, AR\) in the ZAZ region is categorized into distinct groups based on their interdependencies, functionality, and migration requirements. The \*\*first group\*\* consists of 240 \[\[Tier1>>url:https://quip-amazon.com/DMRlAyQAEhF8/DARU-DSA2-Tier1-Pipelines#temp:C:aNc0a7a5f7b84c4474ab75280adb\]\] services, which are tightly coupled, latency sensitive, interdependent \(Pick, Pack, Sort, etc.\) and software stack \(not data\) will be replicated together as a single unit to ensure seamless operation and prevent any disruptions or compatibility issues. The \*\*second group\*\* comprises regional services \(Skumaster, labor planning, etc.\), which do not have a specific warehouse identifier associated with them and asynchronous services \(SNS, SQS, etc.\). The regional services will either continue to operate from DUB, and serve clients in both the DUB and ZAZ regions or create a new stack is created in ZAZ, and ensure data consistency between the DUB and ZAZ stacks to maintain seamless service delivery to clients in their respective regions. The asynchronous services \(SNS, SQS, etc.\) services operate in a decoupled manner, allowing flexibility during the migration process. The \*\*third group\*\* includes non-Tier1 services \(reporting tools\), which, like the asynchronous services, can be replicated and set up in isolation without causing disruptions to other services. Further details can be found in \[\[AFT DARU Program Goals>>url:https://amazon.awsapps.com/workdocs-amazon/index.html#/document/3a1b9e83e808327351ec7ed0acaa004a5f0d2cd06ff5f778f035e800dda536af\]\] document.\\n54: \\n55: \*\*Contact Info:\*\*\\n56: DARU-OTS Program Reference Links Wiki: \[\[https:~~/~~/w.amazon.com/bin/view/OTIE/InfrastructurePrograms/DARU-OTS>>url:https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/OTIE/InfrastructurePrograms/DARU-OTS\]\]\\n57: \\n58: eMail/interest list: \[\[daru-ots-interest@amazon.com>>url:http://daru-ots-interest@amazon.com\]\]\\n59: \\n60: Slack Channel: \[\[#daru-ots-interest>>url:https://amazon.enterprise.slack.com/archives/C094U0C2Z5K\]\]\\n61: \\n62: Weekly DARU Office hours: Every Monday 1:30 PM to 2:30 PM EST \(\[\[Zoom Call link>>url:https://amazon.zoom.us/j/7867175185?pwd=zvPD4GEZqo7qve9rDQtw5EIyMDatMZ.1&omn=97210998831&from=addon\]\]\)\\n\\n"}
